title: Distressed Girl
location: Outer London: Barnet (Greater London) - Field just south of A1081 junction with Trotters Bottom
info: Over a period of around twenty years, calls would arrive at Barnet Police Station from witnesses who claimed to have seen scantily dressed girl in distress standing in a field. The reports would be made early in the morning, and the police were never able to find anyone when they attended the scene, leading them believing the girl to be a ghost.

title: Lady in a Long Dress
info: Tradition says this pond is haunted by a phantom woman wearing a long dress. She may have been seen by a photographer in 2014, during the early hours of the morning, walking a path leading to the pond. A photograph taken in l987 shows a strange grey ghostly figure emerging from the undergrowth.

title: Grey Lady
info: A local story says the church tower is haunted by a grey lady who leapt from the top after being spurned.

title: Roman Coins
location: Watton-at-Stone (Hertfordshire) - Close to the River Beane
info: One story says misfortunes befell the family of a man who found a cache of Roman coins near the river and kept them for himself.

title: Sheppard
info: Footsteps and moving objects have been reported in this pub, where James Sheppard died on the stairs in 1833 after being shot nearby by a police officer.

title: Smugglers
info:
The cellar of the inn is reputedly haunted by two smugglers who drowned during the 
Great Sheffield Flood of 1864.

title: William Shepherd
location: Chichester (Sussex) - Royal Oak public house, Hooksway
info: William 'Shagger' Shepherd, a local sheep rustler who operated in the area during the seventeenth century, died at the hands of a vengeful mob in this building. His presence is said to remain.

title: Touch
info: Curator Leonard Low featured in the local press, sharing his experiences of feeling a phantom hand on his shoulder (which he initially thought belonged to his wife) and other presences in the museum.

title: Mansion
info: While walking their dog, a witness watched a mansion appear. The more the witness looked, the clearer the vision became, before it suddenly vanished.

title: Footsteps
location: Gloucester (Gloucestershire) - Horton Road, Mayhill Way, and London Road
info: During the pandemic, this witness heard footsteps coming up from behind. Conscious of social distancing, the witness stopped and turned around to let the approaching person pass; no one could be seen and after a split second, the footsteps stopped.

title: Mrs Milman
info: A ghost seen around the palace was identified as (the still living) Mrs Milman, and although she worked at the site as Assistant Clerk, she was not present at the time of the sightings. In a contemporary newspaper report, Milman said that she would be spotted in places where she was not present. Around the same time, Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman and other MPs witnessed a colleague sitting in the House of Commons chamber, even though they knew the colleague to be seriously ill at home. In 1989, a lift operator claimed an unseen force picked him up and tossed him fifteen feet along a corridor. More recently, senior aide Jo-Anne Crowder claimed during her time at Westminster she had felt a phantom dog nuzzle up to her, and she had also seen the reflection of an unknown grey lady in glass.

title: Older Lady
info: The upper part of this building was home to a phantom older woman with antisocial tendencies. The entity appeared to one member of staff who popped upstairs to move some stock, causing the witness to quickly retreat.

title: Force
location: Waterford (County Waterford) - By the old infirmary, towards John's Park / Polberry Cross Road
info: A witness walking home in the early hours of the morning was pushed two metres by an unseen force. No one else could be seen. The witness said the sensation resembled a push from a horse and was one of their worst experiences.

title: Dusty Figure
info: A family who moved to a cottage owned by a miller soon observed a figure in dusty white overalls walk through the wall. During renovations it was discovered that the location where the figure had walked through had formally been a doorway.

title: Captain
info: The captain of a boat murdered a little girl and her mother on the site during the nineteenth century. While the captain was said to traditionally haunt the site, one group of people reportedly caught a phantom girl in a photograph.

title: Hanging Man
info: This bar is haunted by a former landlord who, during the 1970s, hanged himself in the cellar. Other spirits also lurk here; a green lady lurks the bar, Willy sits in a room, while Annie has apparently contacted a visiting psychic. The image of a green glowing shape which appeared online in 2023 was dismissed by staff at the bar as a reflection of the emergency exit signage.

title: Cats
location: Hollesley (Suffolk) - Shingle Street and general area
info: In 2004 a prison guard spotted a large cat along a road, and four years later another witness encountered a large brown cat. Big Cats of Suffolk website reported that a forester had been warned by colleagues about large cats in the area during the 1970s, and in 2013 stool, hair and field signs were found.

title: Lady in White
info: Over a period of several months, different people spotted a former owner who took the form of a lady in white standing at the top of the staircase. Visitors would also say that they had seen someone peer into the lounge, even though no one had done so.

title: White Lady
info: A white lady drifts around the grounds of the manor and sometimes the nearby henge and stone circles. The phantom woman's face is covered by a large hood. The inside of the manor house is said to be haunted by several other entities. One spirit would scatter rose petals across the floor of the Crimson Room, and a phantom monk was once spotted in the library. A ghostly Cavalier occasionally makes an appearance, and in 2014, a visitor was left with a sinking feeling after seeing (but not physically) two Victorian-era children swinging from the bannisters.

title: Margaret
info: Margaret fell to her death from the castle tower, trying to escape to secretly meet her lover. She can be heard crying in the area. Another ghost takes the form of a man, seen on the staircase in the older part of the building.

title: Cyril
info: The shadowy phantom Cyril, a former projectionist in a former cinema, can be seen wandering around on the balcony and will sometimes flip a particular seat (third row down in the balcony, and four along). The entity is also blamed for moving objects around.

title: Centaur
location: Isle of Coll (Argyll and Bute) - General area
info: A letter in the Oban Telegraph and West Highland Chronicle referred to islanders being worried by a phantom horse which had human attributes.

title: Woman with Case
location: Dunstable (Bedfordshire) - Road 'two or three' miles north of town
info: An older woman holding an attache case steps off the path into oncoming traffic, dissolving before any impact occurs.

title: Stable Boy
info: A stable boy, killed after being discovered in the bedroom of the owner's daughter, still walks around the building looking for his former girlfriend. The castle also carries stories about being haunted by a former wizard who once resided there, who remains in a trance under the structure (although another variation of the story says he returns to the castle every seven years riding a white horse with silver shoes). More recently, a groundsman spotted a woman and a child heading running along the avenue towards the castle - the figures suddenly vanished. Shadowy figures and disembodied voices have also been reported.

title: Horses and Carriage
location: Droitwich Spa (Hereford & Worcester) - Unnamed road between Droitwich and Worchester
info: A pair of ghostly horses pulling a carriage pass through the gates of an unidentified stately house before setting off along the road.

title: Burnt Out Car
location: Watford (Hertfordshire) - A41 (was A5088), near a fork in the road
info: Turning the corner of this road would reveal a skeletal car resting on the verge, the remains vanishing as headlights fell upon it.

title: Lord Doneraile
info: One piece of nineteenth century folklore, dismissed as fiction by a contemporary newspaper, says Lord Doneraile rides a horse pursuing a fox as punishment for converting a chapel into his kitchen.

title: Bus
location: Lamberhurst (Kent) - Road between town and Frant
info: Witnesses report seeing this vehicle coming towards them along narrow parts of the road; they pull in to give way, only to see the bus vanish. An earlier version of the story says the bus (or coach) is seen parked at the side of the road but vanishes when witnesses pass.

title: Horsemen
info: A cavalcade of ghostly horsemen would ride through this area.

title: Horse
location: Talke (Staffordshire) - Road just outside the village
info: Drivers reported hearing the sound like a hammer striking an anvil before seeing a phantom horse being led across the road, both man and beast cut off at the knees as if walking a much older track since built upon.

title: Lorry
location: Coventry (West Midlands) - A4028 road (now A428?) eastbound, connecting Coventry and Rugby
info: This phantom HGV travelling at speed vanishes just before hitting the vehicle travelling in front of it. Another version of the story dating back to the 1930s says the vehicle moves straight across the road, emerging from a hedge before vanishing into another.

title: Bloody Hand
info: A lorry driver reportedly fainted after a blood-stained hand manifested on his steering wheel. Other drivers passing through the area had encountered a phantom face in the road, the ghostly wreckage of a car. And the sounds of groaning.

title: White Cat
location: York (Yorkshire) - Unnamed streets 'close to a graveyard within the walls'
date: Nineteenth century, but said to appear at midnight on dark nights
info: A white cat (which sometimes took the form of a white rabbit, or vice versa) would wander the streets at night. If seen, the creature would always outrun the pursuer and disappear among the tombstones of a church. Reports of the entity ceased after the introduction of gaslights.

title: Lady
location: Binfield (Berkshire) - Billingbear House, and hawthorn tree (which may no longer exist)
date: Pre-1924 (white lady), hawthorn tree on Christmas Eve (reoccurring)
info: A ghostly white lady haunted this house before it burnt down. One room was transported to Pace College, Manhattan, and is said to contain a ghost (whether it is the white lady is unknown). Another piece of local folklore says a hawthorn tree on the grounds blossoms red flowers at midnight on Christmas Eve before quickly reverting to its previous state.

title: Couple
location: Datchet (Berkshire) - Monastery (destroyed 1920s, only a wall currently remains)
info: A pair of ghosts, one a woman in bright white clothing, the other a tall man dressed in black, were said to sing in the monastery garden before vanishing through a wall.

title: Depressing Atmosphere
info: Haunted by a depressingly sad woman who is occasionally heard sobbing her heart out, her mood is supposed to rub off on people and make them cry. One story says the  woman was married to the landlord but caught having an affair and forced the leave her home and child, dying of a broken heart.

title: Rider
info: The threat of spotting a phantom woman on horseback ensured locals would not use this route after dark.

title: Binjy
location: Wargrave (Berkshire) - River Thames near the High Street
info: The entity known as Binjy would try to lure people into the water of the river.

title: White Stag
info: A white stag, which gained protection from the king who spent a day attempting to hunt the creature, remained to run through the area after its death.

title: Coach and Horses
info: Appearing at midnight on Christmas Eve, a phantom coach pulled by four ghostly horses gallop along this road. Another story (or a variant of the first) states a spectral horse would charge along the road dragging chains which bounced along the ground.

title: Darrie Loughlin
location: Derryveagh Mountains (County Donegal) - Area around Lough Dheerig (possibly Lough Derg?)
info: Around eighteen months after his death, Darrie Loughlin's ghost started to appear in the area, riding a white horse towards the lough.

title: Roger of Salisbury
info: The phantom Bishop Roger of Salisbury may have been spotted at the castle.

title: White Woman
info: A white female phantom is said to hover over the graves of the fallen knights on the site. Another tale says a Knight Templar also haunts the church.

title: Lady Constance
location: Outer London: Bexley (Greater London) - Hall Place
date: Constance unknown, Edward in October 1931, poltergeist 1950
info: One of several ghosts reported here, Lady Constance killed herself after watching her husband die when a stag gored him. Her pale white shade now frequents the grounds. Lady Limerick reported seeing the ghostly Edward, the Black Prince during the First World War, and he popped up again in 1931. The spirit of a servant haunts the loft, while a poltergeist outbreak in 1950 resulted in furniture being tossed around.

title: Madame de Beauclair
info: Madame de Beauclair was a good friend of the Duchess of Mazarine, and both lived in the palace grounds. They made a pact in which the first to die would appear to the other. The Duchess was first to die, and months passed without her ghost appearing. Suddenly one day the ghost appeared to Madame de Beauclair with the warning that the Madame would be dead by the following day. Sure enough, at one in the morning, Madame de Beauclair died. Both women are said to have been seen since, the Duchess of Mazarine by a servant.

title: Monk and Author
info: A phantom monk (or corrupt priest) reputedly haunts the chapel, and a local author also threatened to haunt the location. Mr Reginald Hine, at the start of the twentieth century, said he loved the place so much that he threatened to haunt the church to protect it from any redevelopment work. An unconvincing photograph does exist of the phantom monk/priest.

title: Reverend Norbert Wylie
info: Shortly after dying, the Reverend Norbert Wylie started to appear around the church. Witnesses claimed to have seen the man at the altar, outside the confessional box, and walking through the cloisters. Father Fabian Dix encountered Wylie and heard the ghost say, 'Pray for me', a message he passed on to the congregation.

title: Faceless Monk
info: This giant figure is said to have had a skull for a head, a result of black magic rituals carried out in days gone by. He has made at least one witness drop dead of shock (although the death was also said to have been caused by a phantom old lady in black). The grounds are also haunted by a white lady, gliding effortlessly along.

title: Man and his Dog
location: Birmingham (West Midlands) - Inn (demolished nineteenth century?) near Cathedral
info: The married couple who ran this establishment would occasionally murder a vagrant and sell the body to medical students. After the inn closed and was converted into a house, the new occupants encountered a tall faceless figure with a dog standing by the fireplace. Screams and crashing would also be heard at night.

title: Excavation Assistance
info: During his excavation of the ruined priory, the site's owner Colonel Rivers-Moore engaged in seances on site to guide his work.

title: Bell Ringing
info: The East of Scotland Paranormal Society investigated this building and claimed to have heard footsteps, whispering, and the sound of a bell.

title: Victorian Lady
info: A phantasmal female figure observed on the lower landing of the hotel may have been the daughter of one of the former owners of the building.

title: White Lady
info: The daughter of a previous owner, this shade is thought to have returned after the girl's suicide. She is said to walk down the staircase dressed in nightwear.

title: Maid
info: The centre is said to be haunted by a maid who still loiters around the old top floor flat and along corridors, while a floating face haunts the Green Room. The Aberdeen Ghost Hunters group investigated the site and recorded electrical interference and EVP.

title: Earth Hound
info: Earth hounds are said to be the size of a rat, but with a dog-like head and feet of a mole. They live in churchyards and eat the recently buried. A dead earth hound may have been ploughed up in the Mastrick churchyard.

title: John Walker
info: First spotted by barmaid Agnes McInnes, the ghost of the former landlord Walker is more commonly fleetingly seen.

title: Pensioner
info: The remains of an aging soldier were discovered in a barn along this road; much of the body had been reduced to ash, though the face could be recognised. The bales of straw surrounding him failed to catch fire.

title: Pacing
info: One student reported hearing pacing along a corridor. When investigated, no one could be found in the area. The same student also awoke to hear someone repeating their name, although the room was unoccupied by anyone else at the time. Several years later, one girl encountered a tall dark figure which vanished.

title: Banging
info: The house shook due to unexplained bangs and crashes that emerged from walls and floors. Police on the scene were also unable to track down the source of the sounds. Some blamed the disturbance on the ghost of a blacksmith, who had owned a property under the house and had taken his own life many years previous, although visiting spiritualists claimed the owner's father who died a few years earlier made the sounds.

title: Hooded Figure
location: Aberdeen - Grassy area near a bus stop on the Kincorthland Estate
info: A woman walking to the bus stop on her way to work in the early hours of the morning spotted a cloaked, hooded and masked phantom figure. The woman felt an overwhelming urge to approach the entity, which dissolved like mist and vanished into the grass.

title: Sitting Man
info: A student woke up to discover a man sitting on a chair beside her bed. The student screamed and the figure vanished. Another student in the room next door also claimed to have seen something dark move past while looking in a mirror.

title: Jake
info: A former stagehand who lost his head in an accident at the theatre prior to the Second World War, Jake disappeared after building work ended in 1982. However, when renovation work started again, contractors began to report the sound of someone in high heels walking around empty areas of the theatre.

title: Officer
location: Aberdeen - King Street, former Barracks (currently Grampian Transport?)
info: A Captain with the Gordon Highlanders, this officer lost his bottle prior to being shipped overseas and took his own life. His ghost remains trapped within the building.

title: Watching
location: Aberdeen - Ma Cameron's public house, Little Belmont Street
info: People have reported feelings of being watched in the bar when the area is empty. One story says a decorator fled the site after hearing a series of knocks emerging from an empty room.

title: Silhouette
location: Aberdeen - Old Fire Station, King Street (now student accommodation)
info: A former student who stayed here recalled how a silhouetted figure walked towards him as he stood in the shower - the witness jumped out of the way, injuring his heal. A couple of months later someone told the student that the building had a haunted reputation. It is said that several fire fighters based at the site when operational encountered a figure in Victorian uniform, said to be a man who died while saving a child.

title: Orange Lights
info: A handful of reports concerning strange lights were recorded during 2006. One family observed six orange lights hovering in the sky before appearing to disintegrate.

title: Naked Man
info: This unclothed ghost hammered at the windows of the hotel for the period of a week. When finally spotted and approached, he floated away leaving no footprints in freshly laid snow.

title: Friendly Presence
location: Aberdeen - Private residence, Chaplains' Court, Chanonry
info: Author Agnes Short claimed to have seen a ghostly woman in her home, both gliding along a corridor and sewing while sitting. A small group of phantom men were also spotted sitting around a table. Latter owners said they could feel a friendly presence on the site but never encountered a ghost.

title: Large Purple Fingers
info: Three schoolchildren reported seeing three strange purple fingers with long black nails, unnaturally long, emerging from the cathedral door. They ran.

title: Going Down
info: Two council workers watched a dark haired lady enter a lift, but when they also stepped inside a few seconds later, she had vanished.

title: The Clencher
info: Many people have reported feeling this entity grab their arms or legs, holding on for several seconds before letting go. It is believed to be a little girl who died violently nearby.

title: Indian Child
location: Aberdeen - White Dove Hotel (no longer standing)
info: This young Indian girl manifested and stood by a guest dying of fever in the hotel - the nurse who saw the ghost said it had terrible injuries on the neck, so severe that it caused the nurse to faint. When the nurse regained consciousness, the strange little girl had gone and the patient passed away.

title: Kittie Rankie
info: Burnt as a witch at the top of a nearby hill, Kittie now haunts the castle and the surrounding land.

title: Blood Stains
info: The steps of the building were stained with the blood of a murdered girl - the marks would return, even if scrubbed away. The bloody stains were finally covered over with wood.

title: Piper
info: What is it with inquisitive pipers and tunnels? Playing his pipe while investigating this secret passageway, a man vanished without trace (though, of course, he is now heard).

title: Green Lady
info: The haunting of the site by the green lady began after her husband murdered her.

title: Marching
info: The ghostly sound of long dead English soldiers marching past this building on the lookout for Jacobites could once be heard.

title: Lady in Grey
info: Drifting around the hotel, the grey figure in a sweeping skirt is thought to be mostly harmless.

title: Spinning Jenny
info: Maybe related to the 'washer woman' legends popular in Scotland, this old lady sits on the bank of the stream, spinning her little wheel.

title: Green Lady
info: This spook lurks in the basement of the building.

title: Monk
location: Banchory - A980, Upper Lochton (approximately 1 mile north of Banchory)
info: A figure wearing a habit stepped in front of the car of a man returning from Aberdeen. The driver braked hard, convinced an accident would occur, but the figure vanished around three metres away from the vehicle.

title: Thrower
location: Banchory - Crathes Farm (no longer operating - site now Leys Estate Office?), Baldarroch
info: A story circulated that a poltergeist had established a foothold in this farm, the spirit throwing items around the site. One account says the poltergeist was later discovered to be a serving girl.

title: Bertha
location: Banchory - Loch of Lees Castle (no longer standing?)
info: Bertha died after being poisoned by her lover's mother, not impressed with her son's choice of woman. Bertha had her revenge; she appeared post-mortem and scared her murderer to death. Bertha now returns to the scene of the crime once a year, though no one knows the exact date. Another version of the story places the ghost at Crathes castle, rather than Lees.

title: Pregnant Lady
info: This woman hanged herself rather than face becoming a single parent. A phantom monk has also been reported within the building.

title: Raging Battle
location: Banff - Hill known as Manderlee, four miles from town
info: A phantom raging battle looked so real many people were said to have buried their personal belongings to prevent them falling into the victorious soldiers' hands.

title: Lord Banff
info: Banff's servants murdered their master, who then set the castle alight to conceal their crime. The ghost of Banff is said to have returned, though no one is sure how it manifests.

title: Long Serpent
info: Eight crewmen of a lugger reported seeing a sea creature three hundred feet (ninety metres) long, with three huge humps. The beast made as much noise as a steamer while moving.

title: Beast of Bennachie
info: This big black cat was blamed for dead sheep and causing disruption in the neighbourhood.

title: Fighting Giants
info: A monolith found here features a larger-than-life handprint and footprint - it is said that the prints belong to two giants who fought over the love of a woman.

title: Sergeant Davies
info: Davies' naked or semi-clad ghost appeared in several places after he vanished without trace. When his body was discovered and two men were tried for his murder (though they were found not guilty), the ghost of Davies never appeared again.

title: Plague Victims
info: When the Black Death broke out within the castle, local villagers blocked the external doors so no one could escape and taint the nearby lands - all those who died inside sometimes return to relive their final days.

title: Fairy Stone
location: Braemar - Mill (unlikely to stand) near the River Dee
info: A kelpie crept into the mill at night and used a fairy stone to grind a sack of flour to give to a mortal woman he had taken a liking to. The miller awoke and heading out to his workplace, spotted kelpie leaving the site with the sack of flour over his shoulder. The miller picked up the forgotten fairy stone and lobbed it at the kelpie. The stone struck the kelpie's leg, breaking it, and causing the entity to roll into the River Dee where it drowned.

title: The Black Colonel's Coffin
info: John Farquharson, also known as the Black Colonel, was buried here against his dying wishes. His coffin removed itself from the ground three times before the local clergy took the hint and had John buried closer to his former home.

title: Newly Wed Bride
info: Convinced she had made a bad wife after waking up and finding her new husband gone, this girl leapt off the battlements to her death - unfortunately, her husband had only gone hunting without informing her. She now appears to others, not wanting them to make the same mistake.

title: Bangs
location: Braemar - Disused cottage a few miles out of town (no longer standing)
info: Someone sleeping in this empty, disused cottage found themselves harassed by banging emerging from an empty room.

title: Frozen Maiden
info: The large red monolith is reportedly a maiden who tried to escape from a local warlock - she failed.

title: Rent Collector
info: The rent collector was murdered while visiting the building to collect monies owned. His shade is still reported to haunt the doorway.

title: Dying of Thirst
location: Corgaff - The Well in the Grey Wood, between Corgaff and Glengairn
info: A well in this area was cursed - if a person drinking from the well failed to leave a pin, they would die of thirst.

title: Burning Family
info: A family and servants here where once caught up in a fire and burnt alive - the shades of all twenty-seven people have yet to leave the building and can periodically be heard screaming.

title: Figure in a Habit
location: Crathes - A93 between Banchory and Crathes
info: A ghostly monk is reputed to haunt this stretch of road, upsetting drivers by walking out in front of them. The entity may be related to the monk seen on the A980, near Banchory.

title: City Gent
location: A83 - Past the A815 junction, heading towards ferry
info: Two people travelling to the ferry in the early hours of the morning drove past a man walking along the isolated road. He wore a dark woollen coat with a bowler hat, and carried an umbrella and a briefcase. The night sky was pitch black, and the man did not have a light source. The witnesses remained curious about the figure for years afterwards, as he was so out of place, and later found out the area was haunted by a figure dressed in similar clothing, woefully inadequate for the environment he walks.

title: Clach na Glaistig
info: A stone known as Clach na Glaistig would be washed with a portion of milk every evening to thank a ghost for keeping the calves and cows separate at night. The entity was said to have a face resembling a lichen-covered stone.

title: Mr Stewart
info: Stewart was murdered by the two brothers who once owned the house after they were tricked into selling their property. Sounds of a body being dragged down the staircase have been reported, in addition to the phantom footsteps and the slamming of doors.

title: James of the Glen
info: Landlord Jim Milligan blamed the ghost of James of the Glen for the mild haunting at this inn, which included footstep-like sounds, rattling of swords on the walls, and tipping chairs.

title: Children
info: One room is said to be haunted by ghostly children - people have awoken and believed the children have entered their room by mistake, only for the ghosts to vanish.

title: Death Prediction
location: Ardura, Isle of Mull - Area around Lochbuie House
info: The black dog around this area would warn of impending death. One version of the story says that dog carried a puppy on the back of its head. In 1909, Dr MacDonald spotted the dog while treating chief Murdoch Gillian MacLaine - his patient died soon after.

title: Drowned Man
location: Aros, Isle of Mull - Loch Frisa
info: While the specifics may vary from tale to tale, the loch is named as home to a water horse that drowned a local man known for his dissolute lifestyle.

title: Red Cow
location: Balephuil, Tiree - Farm in the area
info: Dugald Campbell noticed a strange little red cow being attacked by the rest of his herd. The red cow ran off with the rest of the herd giving chase. Campbell followed and watched as the red cow entered a solid piece of rock, closely followed by one of his cows. The rest of the herd, intercepted by Campbell, were prevented from vanishing into the rock.

title: Fairy Home
location: Ballevulin, Tiree - Large sandbank (no longer exists)
info: A large sandbank was once thought to be home to fairies that borrowed the local blacksmith's cauldron every night, returning it in the morning.

title: Ogress
location: Balmaneach, Isle of Mull - MacKinnon's Cave
info: The cave is named after a piper who descended into it the cave to see how far underground he could travel - he bumped into a female ogre who killed him after he failed to please her with a tune from his pipes.

title: Humanoid Beast
location: Balvaig - Area in and around sea, and Grador Rock
info: Incredibly ugly to look at, this monster would sit for many hours on the rock. One man went too close, and he was later found with his flesh clawed off.

title: Drummer
info: Phantom drumming would start whenever a bagpiper played a tune. Through a series of raps, the phantom claimed to have been an Irishman who fell at the Battle of Tel El Kebir in Egypt.

title: Nun
info: Buried alive under the floor of the building, this nun has been seen drifting around the priory.

title: Donald Campbell
info: The same figure that briefly appeared post-mortem at Inverawe House, Donald's shade is said to be full of loathing and hate. A blue lady is said to appear and listen to any music played on site.

title: Short Woman
info: More often heard than seen, when this Glaistig did manifest, she took the form of a very short woman with golden hair that came down to her heels. The entity left after being beaten over the head with a stick.

title: Figure in Black
info: A guest awoke to the sounds of quiet laughter and rummaging. As the guest sat up, they spotted a black-clad figure who vanished when the light was switched on. The guest searched the room but no one was there. After they returned to bed, the guest watched several small balls of light flit around the room. Another visitor to the hotel during the late 1990s reported on a local forum that he had witnessed a dark figure walking around his room before vanishing. The nephew of former owners believed the site to be haunted.

title: Eoghann a' Chin Bhig
location: Ben Buie, Isle of Mull - General area
date: Prior to disaster in the MacLean family
info: Eoghann, while living, tried to kill his father - he was decapitated for his efforts. Now he appears before personal disaster or a death in the family.

title: Grinding
location: Ben Feall, Coll - General area of the hill
info: This hill was home to fairies who could be heard grinding their corn and singing deep within.

title: Bowler Hat Man
info: This mountain is haunted by an old man in a bowler hat. A gold watch chain crosses the figure's waistcoat and he carries a parcel under one arm. It is unclear whether it is the same man which a Glasgow university lecturer encountered while in the area; the figure left no footprints in the snow and said he was going to catch a train before disappearing.

title: Colin Campbell
info: This angry shade, covered in mud and carrying a dirk, is thought to be Colin Roy Campbell, aka the Red Fox, assassinated on 14 May 1752.

title: Goat Man
info: An Urisk banished to the mountain by a saint has remained here since and may lurk in a nearby waterfall.

title: Foot
info: A Glaistig lived behind this waterfall, her foot sticking out just enough to split the falling water into two distinct streams. A member of the Campbell family tried to grab the entity but she escaped, cursing the clan never to have a baby born north of her home.

title: Former Owner
location: Campbeltown - Glen Scotia Scotch Whisky Distillery
info: This distillery is reputed to be haunted by a former owner who drowned himself in the nearby loch after being cheated out of a large amount of money.

title: Shorted Armed Mermaid
info: Watched by a farmer for two hours, this mermaid had a pale upper body and a red/grey tail covered in hair. Its face was human, with deep-set eyes and short neck. The creature combed the hair on its head with what looked like short, stubby arms before diving into the water and washing its torso.

title: Piping
info: Something strange lured a piper into this cave from which he never returned. Hundreds of years later, the piper could still be heard playing his instrument deep below the earth.

title: Long Necked Creature
info: Two local men reported this creature after watching it splashing around in the waters. They described it as having the head and neck of a giraffe, and although the body remained submerged, a dorsal fin could be seen.

title: Coat Tearer
info: One man had a lucky escape from a water horse that emerged from the loch. As the man fled, the creature paused to rip apart a coat that had been left behind, which gave the potential victim enough time to reach his home where his barking dogs drove the water horse away.

title: Milk Snatcher
info: The brownie that took up residence in the MacDonald's home would steal their milk and occasionally create loud noises. The entity had a reputation for hating any Campbells and would also spend time at Largie Castle in Tayinloan.

title: Dark Brown Cat
location: Colonsay - Close to a stone dyke
info: In 1999, a couple visiting the island observed a dark brown large cat, much bigger than a wild cat, roughly the size of a collie. Thirteen years later, the body of a fox was discovered on the island, worrying the locals as no foxes have ever been found here.

title: Macphie's Captor
location: Colonsay - Unknown cave along the coast
info: A mermaid kidnapped a man by the name of Macphie and held him in a cave along the island's shore. Macphie was given any item he wished for but remained unhappy until he managed to escape. The mermaid gave chase, but Macphie tossed his dog into the sea. Dog and mermaid fought until they both died from their injuries.

title: Dog Attack
location: Cornaigbeg (aka Cornaig Beag), Tiree - Land around Cornaigbeg Farm
info: A group of men with a dog were watching over cattle when they heard strange sounds, resembling a herd of sheep, although nothing could be seen. As the sounds passed, the dog chased the invisible entity. The dog later returned but died soon after, its hair scraped off with skin ripped and bloodied.

title: Grey Old Man
info: Seen peering out of the ruins, this grey haired old man was thought to have been involved in the building of the castle.

title: Weaver Beater
location: Craignish - Unknown stream in the area
info: A weaver carrying home a roll of cloth at night found himself attacked by a Glaistig. The phantom pounced as the weaver crossed a stream, and the man found himself remorselessly beaten with his own cloth until dawn.

title: Secret Ball
location: Drimfin (near Tobermory) - Slope near a rock
info: A postman decided to have a quick nap close to a rock known to be the haunt of fairies. The rock opened and a fairy appeared, inviting the postman to a ball. The postman fled and escaped to Tobermory, chased by fairies who probably did not like taking no for an answer.

title: Bagpiper
info: This musician piped a warning to his MacDonald clan leader that he was entering a Campbell trap - as punishment, the Campbells' took the piper and cut off his fingers, leaving him to bleed to death. The bagpiper's warning, a wild and unusual tune, now drifts across the landscape.

title: Giraffe's Neck
location: Firth of Clyde - Cumbrae Islands - waters off Great Cumbrae
info: A partly submerged creature with a neck not dissimilar to that of a giraffe, though it had the head of a camel, was seen in the waters by several fishermen.

title: Tall Woman
location: Ford - Hill between Ardtern and Ford, in the Barbreck Valley
info: Mr Pickop claimed to have encountered a phantom young woman standing on a rock as he climbed the hill to watch the sunset. The entity took the form of a tall woman with black hair and pale skin, wearing a short skirt and a dark tartan plaid. The entity disappeared off the edge of the rock. After the ghost story reached the press, at least one newspaper accused Pickop of fabricating the story.

title: Handprint
info: Over the entrance of the chapel, the imprint of a hand can be seen. This was made by the resident ghost as it tried to grab a tailor who spent the night in the building, the latter character trying (vainly) to disprove the existence of spooks.

title: Charging Beast
location: Gare Loch - Mouth of the loch
info: Two fishermen out collecting lobster pots reported seeing an unidentified creature which rose thirty feet out of the water and charged towards them. They quickly rowed ashore. A sixteenth century text states that a water horse the size of a greyhound emerged and killed three men with as many swipes of its tail; the remainder of the group survived by running away or climbing the trees.

title: Urisk
info: Evidence that shows this part fairy, part human hybrid still to be in the area occasionally turns up. A barrow known locally as the 'Mound of the Dead' is thought to be an entrance to Hell.

title: Healing Waters
info: Once upon a time, people would leave gifts next to the well in return for it bestowing magical waters to the giver.

title: Beithir
location: Glencoe - Ben Vair  (aka Ben Vehir), in a mountain to the south of the area
info: A beithir is an unknown savage animal, sometimes thought to be a serpent or dragon. One such creature was said to have made its home in the mountainous region.

title: Clan MacDonald
info: Murdered in cold blood by the clan Campbell, these 38 MacDonald family members return to the scene of the crime.

title: Q & A
info: Wanting to know why his cows left their enclosure every night, a farmer concealed himself in a nearby hut. The farmer claimed to have encountered a Glaistig and that she answered a series of his questions, although her instructions on how to dodge military conscription failed.

title: Long Creature
location: Helensburgh - Eastern part of the beach, mouth of the Clyde
info: Seen as it crossed the beach and vanished into the sea, the creature was said to have a head around a metre in length. Large footprints were left in the sand. A strong unpleasant smell also remained in the air, and the witness's dog was in an 'upset' state after the sighting.

title: Rooftop Hounds
location: Hynish - Fort at foot of hill in the area
info: This old fort was used by two sons of a local farmer to watch over the family cattle overnight, as the pasture was far from the family home. One evening, the children's mother heard a voice warning her that her sons were in danger. The mother ran to the fort and found her sons terrified, claiming that they had heard fairy hounds stomping and howling on the roof of the fort.

title: Hound Eater
info: Renowned for its dislike of canines (it is blamed for tearing apart stray local hounds), this Cu Sith (sometimes described as a human-wolf hybrid for dramatic effect) has been seen during both day and night.

title: English Soldiers
info: Dressed in red coats, a squad of English troops match in formation along this road. This may relate to a sighting of a phantom army seen in the mid-eighteenth century by two local men - the field where this sighting occurred is now urbanised.

title: Harp Player
info: Executed in 1644, this ghostly musician now returns and plucks his strings around the time of a Duke of Argyll's death. He is also heard in the library throwing books around, though none are ever moved.

title: Battleground
info: A total of five witnesses in two different places watched a battle over the skies of the castle, between the Highlander regiment and garrisoned French troops. This mirrored real events in America, where 300 Highlanders were killed assaulting a fort.

title: Sputnik?
info: Three months after a shepherd reported finding strange wreckage, a team from RAF Kinloss visited the site in October and removed debris consisting of a box and some bottles. While some people believe the craft was a Russian satellite, others say it was an American spy balloon.

title: Potato Thrower
location: Ardgay - Private house, exact location unknown
info: The unsettled spirit here threw potatoes and other vegetables at a minister who came to investigate the disturbance - the entity was finally identified as the shade of a young baby killed by its mother.

title: Voyeuristic Maid
info: This grey lady is often seen just outside the house, either peeping in through the windows, or drifting over the lawn. Another shade, face covered by a hood, has been observed inside the building, while sometimes a strange and unrecognised perfume fills parts of the house.

title: Isobel Gowdie
info: Tried for witchcraft in 1662, Isobel Gowdie claimed she could transform into a hare and had met the queen of the fairies under a hill. Her phantom was spotted by Robin Green, a retired soldier, as he camped in the area.

title: Annie Fraser
info: The entity heard moving around the building is named as a young woman murdered by a jealous suitor. He concealed the woman's body under the floorboards of the building.

title: Granite Stones
info: A legend says that five cylinder shaped stones mark the spot where the last of the Comyns family is buried. The stones vanish and reappear depending on how the House of Rothiemurchus is fairing, but if moved or taken by a human hand, that person is doomed to die. One story says the stones where stolen by a group of people who were later found dead in a car, the stones discovered standing upright nearby.

title: Mrs Boulton
info: A woman who visited the house claimed to have been there before, though only in her dreams. To her surprise, the owner of the property agreed, saying that her visitor resembled a ghost that had been seen there several times! Two more traditional ghosts can be found here; seen approaching the house on horseback, a spectral rider dismounts before vanishing on the driveway, while a scruffy little man has been seen near the front gate.

title: Hovering Light
date: Prior to a death of a Stewart chieftain
info: An orb of brilliant light was said to appear and hover over the castle just before the death of a clan Stewart chieftain.

title: Black Andrew
info: Andrew terrorised the neighbourhood, raping and murdering the locals. They decided to act against the laird, storming his castle and hanging him by the neck from the highest window. Now his shade remains within the walls of the building, though he still harasses visiting women. A much gentler shade has been seen here, a young green-eyed girl who smiles fondly at passers-by.

title: Buildings
info: A woman taking a polaroid photograph of the beach was amazed to see two buildings and a shadowy post on the developed image - no buildings were in the frame as she pressed the camera shutter. An analysis of the image suggested that it was an under exposed image of a farm.

title: Devil's Hand
info: A stone doorway is said to display the mark of Satan.

title: Young Girl
location: Ben Alder - Below the mountain, en route for Loch Ossian
info: Having traversed old drover track on western shoulder of Ben Alder, a walker was looking for a suitable spot to cross a stream. The walker noticed the image of a smiling young girl, dressed in blue/green watery outfit, sitting on a slab of rock amidst the fast moving water. She was pointing to the water, enticing the walker to cross. The walker panicked and moved further downstream, crossing at a point where the water was calmer.

title: Grey Figure
info: While approaching the cloud line, a climber noticed a grey figure 20 yards (18 metres) in front of him. The figure was walking steadily, wearing old hiking gear. The climber tried to catch him up., but no matter how fast he went he could not close the gap between himself and the figure. The climber followed him to the top of the mountain, where he disappeared.

title: Dyeing Fairies
location: Ben Lomond - Green Loch (An Lochan Uaine)
info: The fairies would be happy to dye wool or cloth left by the side of the loch. Unfortunately, one person left unclear instructions on what colour to dye some thread, resulting in the fairies permanently ceasing their work.

title: Music
location: Ben MacDhui ((aka Ben MacDhui, Mac Dhui)) - General area
info: Debates in the media ensured after reports of ghostly music were published. While some favoured the supernatural, others claimed the sounds were created by wind blowing through rocky funnels caused by water erosion.

title: Four Legged Man
location: Ben MacDhui ((aka Ben MacDhui, Mac Dhui)) - Rothiemurchus Forest
date: First entity in the twentieth century, the latter reoccurring to mark tragedies
info: Several people report having been chased by an invisible entity that 'felt' semi-human but could be heard pounding along on hooves. All the witnesses reported feeling extreme terror. An entity known as the Bod-an-Dun also haunts the area, appearing to mark a tragedy in the Grant family that once owned the land.

title: Fear Liath Mor
location: Ben MacDhui (aka Ben MacDhui, Mac Dhui) - High on Mountain
info: Popularly referred to as Britain's yeti relation, the Fear Liath Mor has been heard, seen, and felt by dozens of mountaineers over the past 150 years. The sound of snow being compacted by large feet has made climbers scarper back down the slopes; those who have seen the creature say it is more man than ape, but still covered in grey or brown hair, with long arms and a large head, and standing around twenty foot in height. During the Weird Weekend 2009, researcher Andy Roberts presented a compelling argument that the Fear Liath Mor is more a feeling of dread than a biological entity.

title: Cursed Stone
info: When the waters are low, an inscribed stone can be seen in the river - it is believed cursed, and anyone who meddles with it is doomed. Adding to the treachery of the waters, a white horse is said to patrol the river, looking for people to drown.

title: The Cook
location: Boat of Garten - The Boat Hotel
info: This brave man was murdered while trying to save a fellow worker from an assault. He now periodically appears in the hotel.

title: Future Train
location: Bonar Bridge - Site of railway line
info: Two men walking through the area watched a train pass them by. This was, however, years before railway tracks had been laid through the area.

title: Herbivore Heist
location: Brackletter - Field of the White Cow
info: Fairies stole a white cow but returned to the farmer's field every night to let it graze. The farmer and his dog would give chase, but the fairies would escape by throwing bread that the dog would stop to eat.

title: Woman with Child
info: A doctor out for a walk along the coast watched a light slowly drift across the sea and land nearby. It changed into a cloaked woman holding onto a small child, before vanishing completely. When the doctor told his story at the inn where he was staying, the landlord explained that a few years previously two bodies had been washed up on the coast - that of a woman and child.

title: Mist
location: Broadford, Isle of Skye - Broadford Hotel
info: Mist like figures have been reported here in the past, as have a former housemaid, although the hotel now appears quiet.

title: Red Flying Squid
location: Broadford, Isle of Skye - Coast near the area
info: Constable John Morrison kicked a squid he found on a beach, only for the creature to wrap a 180 centimetre tentacle around his ankle. The policeman managed to remove his boot and killed the cephalopod with rocks and a set of shears.

title: Famh
info: This author is not sure if this is a joke, but... the Famh is said to be a strange dog/mole hybrid (Dole? Mog?), which possesses a vicious set of teeth and a disproportionately sized mouth. It lurks in the mountain range, shying away from human contact. The area is also haunted by a piper, who is seen standing on the tallest peaks, and is heard playing at night.

title: Treasure Under A Stone
location: Carn Glas - Rock on the mountain
date: Said to have occurred early nineteenth century
info: A man had a dream that if he went to the mountain on Monday morning, he would see a crow sitting on a stone, and under this stone would be treasure that once belonged to a Norwegian prince. Unfortunately, the man was impatient and set off early, arriving Sunday evening to find hundreds of crows, each sitting on a different rock.

title: Mean Old Dog
location: Clachtoll - Main road through the village
info: This phantom hound is said to harass those using the road late at night. It can easily be recognised by its pair of horns.

title: Fairy Music
info: A Bronze Age cemetery, the haunting sound of fiddling heard in this area has led some to say that the music is produced by fairies. A few people who have removed stones from the site are reported have returned them after suffering streaks of bad luck.

title: Drowning Entity
info: The river is home to an entity that has been known to grab people and hold them underwater until drowning occurs. Only then will the presence let the body float to the surface. Unrelated to this, the river is also home to the King Otter - this large water mammal is said to be much larger than its more common siblings, and if caught will grant a single wish in return for its freedom.

title: Highlander with Hounds
location: Corrieyairack Pass - Bridge over a stream
info: This shade is said to guide people to the bridge when the weather becomes treacherous.

title: Artist's House
location: Craignure - Unidentified house, Grasspoint (aka Grass Point)
info: Author and Sculptor Lionel Leslie lived in a reputed haunted house here, although the exact details of the phantom are not known.

title: Human-faced Dog
location: Creag an Ordain - B869, between Stoer and Lochinver
info: On closer examination, this shuck has the horrible face of a person, with little devil-like horns. If it barks more than two times, disaster will follow shortly.

title: Murdered Miller
info: This ghost appeared to a local postman and another gentleman as they passed through the wooded area - it is thought the ghost told them who his murderer was, though it appears the two witnesses did not act on the information provided.

title: Old Hag
location: Cromarty - Nearby moorland and wooded areas
info: Many ghostly figures have been reported here; armoured knights, old hags, and other figures which run through the trees laughing and screaming. There is also a story about a beautiful woman who tries to lure men into swampland to drown.

title: Smoky Rabbit
location: Cromarty - Old castle (no longer standing, replaced by Cromarty House)
info: Several strange shades frequented the castle, including a rabbit that would turn into smoke, a small pixie-like bearded man, and heavy pacing.

title: Fairies' Cradle
location: Cromarty - Stone near St Benet's Spring (spring may no longer exist)
info: If a baby had been replaced by a changeling, the fairy child could be placed on a stone known as the Fairies' Cradle and the little people were forced to return the stolen human child. The stone was broken up by a minister.

title: Backwards Gravity
location: Croy Brae - Hill along the A719
info: More of an optical illusion, really. The environment surrounding the hill creates the illusion that the hill is really going up, rather than down, which confuses passing tourists and visitors to the area.

title: MacRaing
location: Cullin Hills, Isle of Skye - General area
info: A murdering robber, MacRaing killed his own son after the lad threatened to turn him over to the law. His ghost now roams the mountain range.

title: Bonnie Prince Charlie
info: This shade is said to haunt the hotel, though much of the original building has been replaced.

title: Highlander
info: The single, solitary highlander seen walking on the site is thought to be one of the many killed by English soldiers on 16 April 1746. He has also been observed lying on top of a burial mound. Sorche Nic Leodhas writes that one person has seen the entire battle re-fought, 150 years after the actual event, while in 2006 a family heard horse's hooves but could see nothing.

title: Wine
date: 01 May (reoccurring), or first Sunday in May
info: This holy well would be visited to heal the sick on the first Sunday in May - a piece of cloth would be dipped in the water before being hung from the branch of a nearby tree. One myth says that on Mayday the water turned to wine.

title: Piper
location: Culrain - Carbisdale Castle (aka Castle of Spite)
info: Though only a hundred years old, the castle is said to be haunted by a traditional piper and a lady in white, the latter named as Duchess Blair (or Betty, for short).

title: Game of Shinty
location: Dalarossie, Inverness - Land near the local church
date: 25 December, when it falls on a Sunday (reoccurring)
info: These people, during life, made the mistake of playing sports when Christmas day fell on a Sabbath. Now they all return from the grave for a quick game once a year.

title: Bleeding Witch
info: Two witnesses reported seeing the shade of an old witch running away from several hunting hounds - this relates to a local legend, in which the old hag tries (unsuccessfully) to murder a huntsman.

title: Whispering
info: If one listens carefully, the sound of someone breathing heavily can be heard here. Occasionally the sounds change into whispers and groans.

title: Gibbering
info: Strange sounds have been reported coming from this estate, a mixture of laughing, moaning and inane chattering.

title: Two Little Girls
info: A guest staying the night in this room reported feeling the two adolescent girls sitting on his chest as he lay in bed, as if trying to suffocate him. Previous guests in the room have reported a figure sitting at the end of their bed, door handles rattling, and other strange disturbances. The castle is also known for its Green Lady, who died after falling down a spiral staircase after witnessing her father's adultery.

title: Grey Lady
info: Little is known about this off-white spook that reportedly drifts around the strong house.

title: Bridge Builders
info: Water spirits would cross this body of water in seashells but found the method very tiresome. A team of kelpies started building a bridge made of gold and had almost finished their endeavour when a passing man blessed them on their work. The workmen vanished and the bridge collapsed, turning into a sandbank.

title: Banshee in Green
info: The banshee which reputedly lives here is clad in green silks. A farmer's wife who spotted the entity said it sat quietly on a rock, had long blonde hair and was quite beautiful, although it had no nose.

title: Monk
info: Longing to rejoin the order from which he was kicked out from, this monk is still seen drifting in the area, and is believed to be evil.

title: Lady Montgomery
info: This woman was killed by her husband after he discovered the heinous ways in which she treated the local peasants.

title: Small Girl
info: A phantom young person is said be heard running around the building when it should be empty. A photograph is said to exist of the phantom.

title: Rotting Carcass
info: The decaying body of a strange creature, with neck as long as the body, was discovered by two local council workers. They estimated the length to be around twenty-eight feet (just under nine metres). The men were ordered to destroy the corpse by the Royal Navy, who were using the area at the time. Another serpent sighting in the area occurred in 1913; this time the creature was alive and well and swimming in the river.

title: Weather Controller
location: Gourock - The Kempock Stone (aka Granny Kempock)
info: It was once thought that the stone could control the weather; prior to fishing journeys, the fishermen would leave gifts at the base of the rock or walk seven times around it whilst chanting. In 1662 a 'witch' claimed she had managed to raise storms by abusing the power of the stone.

title: Black Leopard
info: A Greenock couple were surprised to find a large black cat in their front garden which quickly ran away. It is believed that there is at least one adult ABC and two cubs living in the area.

title: Green Light
info: This witness spotted a solid green glowing ufo with an orange trail as it crossed the sky heading east. The object generated no sound.

title: Old Fashioned Mann
info: Working in the hall one afternoon, two people spotted a man dressed in clothing from around the 1800s enter the kitchen. They followed the figure, but he had vanished - all possible exits were secure. The witnesses checked CCTV footage, but they could only see themselves on the camera. The building is also said to be home to a small boy who fell to his death in the nineteenth century and can now be observed sitting to the left of the top balcony facing away from the stage.

title: Steam
info: A family moved from their council home after coming under attack from a poltergeist - steam would quickly appear and disappear, scratching could be heard, and one child in the house reported seeing shadowy figures.

title: Deer Hunter
info: A local hill walker discovered a baby deer which had been torn apart. The man speculated it was killed by a large cat, as the damage done to the dead creature far surpassed anything he had encountered before.

title: Victorian in Black
location: Kilmacolm - Bend in the road entering the town
info: This Victorian woman dressed in a sweeping black dress haunts the road into the village, and drifts three foot above the ground.

title: Shawled Woman
location: Port Glasgow - Private residence near  Bogston station
info: A visitor to this home briefly encountered a woman dressed in traditional Scottish fishwife attire standing over their newborn child. When the woman realised she had been spotted, she held out her hands before vanishing. When asked, the owner of the property said that they had seen and heard things on the site, and felt the presence looked after them.

title: Elderly Lady
info: While two men stocked the bar ready for a Christmas party, one of the pair met an elderly lady on the middle landing who informed him that she had 'finished for the night'. A short while later, the man told his colleague about the meeting, who insisted that they were the only people in the building. It was reported that others have also met the woman, who is always happy to talk.

title: Nuckelavee
info: A hybrid, sea living creature, the Nuckelavee was described as having the features of both a mighty horse and its rider. The rider was legless and appeared to grow straight out of the horse's back. Its head was ten times the size of a normal human head, possessing a very wide mouth that jutted out like a pig's snout, and a single red eye that blazed with flame. It was both hairless and skinless. Nuckelavee's breath was toxic and it was responsible for the 'Mortasheen', a fatal disease of cattle.

title: Good Looking Woman
info: A wife and husband witnessed a mermaid sitting on the rocks, described as 'good looking' by the wife. The couple tried to capture the creature, but it swam away.

title: Walking Stone
location: Birsay - Standing Stone in the area
info: At the stroke of midnight on Hogmanay, this stone would walk down to Birsay loch and would briefly dip its head into the water before moving back to its original location. Anyone foolish enough to try to observe the stone at this time would be found dead the following morning, laying by the base of the stone.

title: Mermaids
info: These women of the water were seen dozens of times during the last twenty years of the nineteenth century. One was said to have been shot, but the body was not recovered.

title: Vanishing Twitchers
info: Two birdwatchers that vanished without trace on the island after arriving with 86 other people were thought by locals to have been taken by merfolk. An extensive search by the coastguard could find no trace of the missing people.

title: Bleeding Ears
info: Another local legend says that the ears of corn which grow here bleed if cut after dusk.

title: White Horse of Clumly
info: Both horse and rider were killed in an accident as they galloped back home, the rider having just disposed of a body. Now the pair only appear when the environment is right.

title: Scapasaurus
info: The rotting corpse of a basking shark that washed up on the beach was mistaken as a Scapasaurus or sea monster, killed by depth charges.

title: Angry Little Men
info: Seen by a witness throwing themselves off the cliff edge in a mad dance, the witness said that these small men looked 'primitive', with long dark hair.

title: Disappearing Collie
location: Hoy - Former lodge of Melsetter House
info: This phantom dog slowly disappeared as it approached the witness down a corridor in their holiday home.

title: Water Horse
info: This creature would attack anyone using the bridge over the burn at night.

title: Water Horse
info: The water horse that lived on the hill would attack people travelling along the road to Longhope.

title: Soft Landing
info: A young lad sitting on the rocks claimed he was attacked by a sea monster with a horse's mane - it tried (unsuccessfully) to clamp its teeth around his legs. Many years later, a diver reported descending to investigate a sunken German ship, only to realise he was standing on the back of a large sea monster that had made its home in the wreak.

title: Dead Creature
location: Isle of Hunda - Hope of Hunda
info: The remains of a creature some 8.5 metres long were originally named as being that of a Scapasaurus, although later revealed to be a carcass of a basking shark.

title: Hybrid
location: Isle of Sanday - Exact area not known
info: Folklorist Walter Traill Dennison recorded in 1893 that there were decedents of a union between a male selkie and a woman living on the island - you could tell who the offspring were because they had webbed hands and feet.

title: Island Covered in Buildings
location: Isle of Sanday - In the sky off coast of the island
info: This island, covered in fantastic white buildings, has appeared twice in the sky just off the coast. On one instance it remained viable for most of the day. Some people believe it to be the Fairy Isle, while others say it was a mirage of a part of Norway.

title: Black Lady of Scar
info: This phantom woman, known as Black Lady of Scar, was reputed to have been pushed overboard by the from a ship on a passage back to Scotland from India. She had married the laird of Scar in India, but while travelling home with her husband, he decided that the marriage was a mistake and murdered her.

title: Not a Seal
info: Two children out picking whelks were shocked when they encountered a mystery sea creature at the water's edge. They described it as being black in colour and far bigger than a seal.

title: Tailed Sphere
info: The Kirkwall coastguard reported a very bright spherical object with a tail, moving north west to the south east. The object then split in two. The Aberdeen coastguard reported seeing the same or similar two objects a little later.

title: White Nun
location: Kirkwall - St Magnus Cathedral and Bishop's Palace
info: Walking around the cathedral three times at midnight shall summon a ghostly white nun. Somewhere underneath the site a phantom piper walks around ancient tunnels which connect to the Bishop's Palace.

title: Hogboy
info: Hogboy was the name of a hogboon, a dark and moody family spirit which lived in the cairns and became upset if milk was not offered to them after a birth or marriage in a family. This hogboon was blamed for several deaths of people and animal on a nearby farm, after the farmer ploughed up a burial mound.

title: Whale like Creature
info: Fishermen reported a whale with characteristics of a boar in the sea in this area.

title: Therianthropy
location: North Ronaldsay - Exact location not known
info: The Goodman of Wastness, a farmer by trade, stole a selkie's seal skin and hid it, forcing the woman to become his wife. After many years of marriage and a house full of children the selkie found her seal skin and ran off back to the sea, never to be seen again.

title: Ubby
info: Ubby is said to be a former owner of the house responsible for constructing the artificial island in the nearby loch. His ghost is one of several friendly entities which haunt the house, which also include a tall man with dark hair and the smell of cigarette smoke.

title: Great Auk
info: Reports of an extinct Great Auk being spotted alive on a beach 142 years after the last confirmed sighting turned out to be nothing more than a hoax.

title: Red Water
info: The waters of the loch are said to turn red just prior to news that will greatly affect the royal family.

title: Swelkie
info: The whirlpool that forms here is thought to be created by the turning of a mill stone to grind salt, ensuring the sea remains salty. Some say the wheel is turned by a sea-witch, while others name the grinders as Fenia and Menia, two local giants.

title: Dog Faced Beast
info: The body of water was home to a sea creature with a long thick neck and a small head resembling that of a dog. It swam under one witness's boat.

title: Tall Creature
info: Observed by a lone lighthouse keeper, this sea monster was seen to rise almost ten metres clear of the waves. A smaller creature had been seen fifteen years earlier by a fishing boat crew and a holiday maker.

title: Candle Light
date: Prior to birth or death in family
info: Once owned by the Balfour family, a ghostly light flickering at the castle window still shines when a birth or death occurs in the family. Deaths are also announced by the howls of a shuck-like creature (known as the Boky Hound), while the ghost of a creature with enormous strength stalks the ruins. This paranormally busy castle was also home to a helpful brownie named Broonie who ensured boats remained safe during storms.

title: Wilkie
location: Pierowall, Westray - Knoll in the area
info: Milk would be poured daily into a hole in this knoll, to appease the entity known as Wilkie. If anyone refused to donate their fair share, they risked clothing being stolen or their cattle dropping dead.

title: Horse o' Hillaroo
info: A winged horse was said to be found atop of the mound of Hillaroo. The horse would swoop down on unlucky travellers, favouring children, and carry them off to an unknown fate.

title: Nuggle
info: Appearing as a beautiful black horse, this creature would hide amongst 'real' horses near the water's edge. True to water horse form, if anyone mounted the beast it would head straight for the water to drown the unsuspecting rider.

title: Water Horse
info: Legend says this island was home to a water horse, although nothing more is known.

title: Ewe
location: Sandwick - Nether Benzieclett farm (no longer standing)
info: The phantom of a murdered man returned in the form of an ewe, appearing at the scene of the crime every morning at 1am.

title: Trotting Dog
location: Sandwick - Road between Sandwick and Birsay
info: Only appearing at night, a strange hound would trot alongside anyone walking between the two areas.

title: Scaly Horse
info: A creature with the body of a horse was observed by several fishermen, who reported it had scales like a fish, and a spotted effect over its body.

title: Glowing Lights
info: No one ever went close enough to discover whether the lights that darted over the area were ghostly torches or will o' the wisps.

title: Camel Headed Creature
location: Skerries of Work - Sea in the area
info: The arrival of this creature was introduced by a school of whales leaping from the water and fleeing the area. The head and neck of the sea monster reached out of the water at the height of a small sailboat.

title: The Stronsa Beast
info: This grey, seventeen metre long creature was first seen floating dead in the sea, before a storm washed it on the beach. It reportedly possessed six legs and had a mane along its back and tail. Another storm which hit the island soon after the discovery destroyed the corpse. The creature was finally declared to be a rotting basking shark carcass, though the body was five metres longer than the largest basking shark ever recorded.

title: Hammering
info: Carpenter John Spence, and his wife, children and servant all heard hammering during the night, although no source could be tracked down. The sounds became louder over the months and were joined by the distressed moans. Eventually John invoked the Holy Trinity and commanded the entity to speak. After listening to further moans, the sounds ceased and never returned.

title: Troll Home
info: Several stories exist around this stone. One says it was thrown into location by an angry giant and became the home of a passing troll. Another says it was the home of a giant and his wife, while a third names the occupant as a dwarf named Trollid.

title: Humped Creature
location: Achmore, Isle of Lewis - Loch Urabhal
info: While fishing, two teachers watched a small headed creature with a single hump swim past their boat some thirty-five metres away. It surfaced three times before disappearing.

title: The Otter King
location: All over the region - No exact location given
info: Martin Martin recorded the tradition of a large otter with a white spot upon its breast. It was said that the king otter was always accompanied by seven normal otters. The pelt of the Otter King was said to offer magical properties to those who owned it.

title: Executed Man
location: Arnish - Loch along A858 between town and Stornoway?
info: Local tradition tells says that this man was executed in Stornoway for murdering a student who had accompanied him on a bird hunting trip. The ghost is said to haunt the spot of the killing.

title: Women with Child
info: Crofter Colin Campbell raised his rifle to fire at what he thought was an otter eating a fish but stopped when he realised the creature was a mermaid holding a child. The creature dived into the sea after Campbell made a noise.

title: Foretelling War
location: Barra - Spring at Kilbarry (location may no longer exist)
info: Pieces of peat would float in this spring when peace reigned, but in times of war, the water would contain flakes of blood.

title: Seafarers
info: A house built on the site where the bodies of two mariners were washed ashore remained empty for many years; whenever someone moved in, they left a few days later, although the exact details of the manifestations are lacking.

title: Blobster
info: A dead four metre long creature was washed up on the beach, with diamond shaped fins sitting along its back - the creature could not be identified.

title: Sluagh
info: The Sluagh are a fairy host that travel across the sky to the land of the ever young, Tir-nan-Og. A couple of hunting hounds belonging to the Sluagh are said to have landed in Benbecula briefly before heading off on their travels.

title: Unseen Tarbh-uisge
location: Borerary, St Kilda - Exact location not known
info: During one dark and stormy evening one of several men sheltering in a hut wished that he had a fat ox. No sooner had he wished for one, there could be heard a bull just outside. However, all in the hut were too terrified to look and see what had appeared. It was only next morning when they ventured out, they found plenty of cloven hoof track but no sign of what had left them.

title: The Third Brother
location: Bragar - Old mill (may no longer exist)
info: Two brothers worked in the mill. One brother would work while the other slept. One day, the working brother watched a figure, who he recognised as another one of his brothers who had recently died, walk over to the sleeping brother and kiss him before disappearing. The brother who received the kiss died a few days later.

title: Mysterious Stones
location: Callanish, Isle of Lewis - Callanish standing stones
info: It is still argued to what extent this stone circle represents the heavenly bodies above, and what its ultimate purpose was. One legend says that the thirteen stones were giants who refused to become Christians - they were petrified for the sin.

title: Each Uisge
info: A local girl had a narrow escape after encountering a water horse which had taken the form of young man by the edge of the loch, only realising his true nature after spotting sand and mud in his hair. She fled home and told her brother, who killed it with his sword the following morning.

title: Wish Granter
info: A local man caught a mermaid on the rocks, only releasing the creature after she agreed to grant three wishes. One of the wishes ensured the man became a skilled doctor, another granted the gift of prophecy, but the third wish, to become a great singer, apparently failed.

title: Vanishing Keepers
info: The three keepers who vanished from the lighthouse left their log behind, which reported they had been rocked by storms over a five day period. However, the surrounding towns and villages reported that the weather had been calm.

title: Gallan Whale
location: Gallan Head, Isle of Lewis - Off coast
info: Martin Martin reported that a large mystery whale terrorised the fishing boats of Gallan Head. It would deliberately sink the boats before returning to eat the crew.

title: Cro Sith
info: Dun and hornless fairy cattle were once thought to live along the coast of Bernera and under the nearby waters.

title: Long Necked Creature
location: Isle of Canna - Off the coast, and around surrounding islands
info: This creature, mistaken for a rock when first observed, was seen at various times by up to thirteen fishing boat crews. It was described as between 70 and 80 foot in length (21 - 24 metres) and possessing a long neck which it kept underwater whilst swimming.

title: Glowing Balls
location: Isle of Lewis - Area around Sandwick
info: The lights that float around the area normally announce approaching death for a local. Some say the light belongs to an Irish merchant robbed and murdered on the island. One legend says that a witness who spoke to the ghost of the merchant was awarded a fairy dog's tooth that enabled the holder to cure ills and punish the greedy.

title: Serpent
location: Isle of Lewis - Broad Bay area
info: A sea serpent spent a couple of weeks at this location, playing in the water. The creature, described as between 18 and 24 metres in length, had a mane like a horse and appeared white in colour.

title: Feolagan
info: The Feolagan was a small mouse-sized creature (or fairy) that would paralyse sheep by walking across the animal's back. The sheep would die unless the Feolagan was forced retrace its steps, or, if many sheep were affected, by capturing the Feolagan in a jar filled with salt and using the grains to cure the sheep.

title: Searrach Uisge
info: Resembling a capsized boat, this creature has been reported swimming around for one and a half centuries. Locals say lambs were once offered annually to the creature.

title: Bumpy Beast
location: Isle of Lewis - Sea off the north of the island
info: A German ship 15 kilometres off the coast reported a sea serpent around 40 metres in length, several bumps protruding from the water, along the creatures back. Sea serpents have also been reported at the southern side of the island.

title: Potato Eater
info: A crofter noticed his potato store was raided each night. One morning he discovered the tooth of a Cu Sith stuck in a potato - looks like this Cu Sith liked a meal of spuds!

title: Jumping Peat
location: Isle of Lewis - Unknown cottage on west side of island
info: Mrs MacLeod, with her two grandchildren experienced a very brief poltergeist outbreak, during which a small piece of peat jumped from the floor and landed in her cup of tea. Crockery scattered itself around the floor, tins thrown into the bedroom, and another piece of peat struck MacLeod in the face.

title: Fillan
location: Isle of Skye - No exact location documented
info: Martin Martin documented a small worm that lived between the flesh and skin, known as either a Fiollan or Fillan. It was about 2.5 centimetres in length, as wide as a goose quill, and it had little legs either side of the body that enabled it to crawl around under the skin. Once there, it would cause tumours and abscesses.

title: Water Kelpie
info: This thirteen metre long creature was described as eel-like, with huge fins that broke the water as it periodically emerged. Witnesses watched the beast eat a blanket that had accidentally been left on the beach.

title: Screaming Monster
location: Loch Duvat, Eriskay - North side of the loch
info: While out looking for a horse that escaped his farm in the mist, a farmer saw what he thought was his missing beast in the loch. As he approached, he realised he was looking at a water monster; the creature gave an unearthly yell, sending the farmer running home and disturbing all the wildlife around the water.

title: Werewolves
location: Loch Langavat, Isle of Lewis - Exact area unknown
info: The island was once home to a colony of wolfmen - even though they are extinct, disturbing their graves is reported to release their spirits.

title: Lamb Eater
location: Loch Suainaval, Isle of Lewis - Waters of the loch
info: It has been reported that lambs were thrown into this loch to feed the creature which lived within.

title: Faery Dog
info: This hound has been known to leave oversized paw prints on the damp sand which vanish suddenly halfway across the beach.

title: Cro Sith
info: The Cro sith were fairy cattle that lived under the sea, occasionally coming ashore. When they did reach land, local farmers would try and catch them to add them to their own herds.

title: Battling Bull
