info: The vault beneath this castle was said to be home to the most awful sounds, either caused by the souls of former prisoners or the waves crashing against the rocks.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Donn of the Sandhills
location: Dough - Close to the site of the old castle
info: Donn was said to be one of the most powerful fairy kings, but he was forgotten about as he lacked a bard to sing his praises.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man with Dog
location: Drumcliff - Around the ruins of the round tower
info: It was said that this phantom man with his ghostly hound would walk quickly around the area.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Black Dog
location: Drumcliff (aka Drumcliffe) - Exact location not known
info: Once thought to haunt this area, the phantom black hound would appear to be mostly forgotten about.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Old Lady
info: Seen standing on the staircase, this little elderly lady sometimes makes an appearance when visitors arrive.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strange Staircase
info: Part of the hotel includes the former town hall which contained a jail, the staircase of which had been reported as haunted. The hotel retains a reputation as being home to some kind of phantom, although exact details are fleeting.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Procession of Monks
info: Thought to be heading towards the abbey, a line of phantom monks would walk slowly through the park.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Corpse Candles
location: Ennis - Ruins of Killone Abbey Convent
date: Unknown, likely to be nineteenth century
info: Lights which darted around the headstones were once said to haunt these ruins.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Child
location: Ennistymon - Private cottage, south side of town
info: A visitor to the cottage fell ill at ease and became convinced that it was haunted, something to do with the death of a child. Another visitor to the cottage experienced nothing in the building but felt that the town had 'the guts and heart knocked out of it.' Later research revealed that several children had been murdered close to the cottage by Crown Auxiliaries during the War of Independence.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Black Hound
location: Ennistymon (aka Ennistimon) - Ennistymon House (now Falls Hotel)
info: The grounds around this house were said to be home to a black dog, which despite its size, was quite harmless.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coach
location: Ennistymon (aka Ennistimon) - Wooded glen near stream/waterfall
info: A servant of the MacNamaras family heard a phantom coach while walking through this area. He ran, opening gates to let the invisible vehicle through, and it drove past him on the third gate. The family later learned that Admiral Sir Burton MacNamara had died in London.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Singing
info: Fairy song was said to have been heard coming from this fort.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Burning Windows
info: The windows of this ruined castle were said to glow with blue fire when observed from a distance - when approached, the illusion would vanish.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Little Old Woman
info: This banshee was witnessed by a group of young people from the same family passing the church at night. They spotted an elderly woman with long white hair clapping her hands and wailing. The male members of the group approached the figure, but she vanished. A few days later they heard one of the older members of the family had died while in Dublin.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lisananima
location: Kilcorney - Fort (may no longer be present)
info: Once known as Lisananima, this fort was said to be haunted by an unknown entity.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Beast with Horse's Head
location: Kilkee - Off coast and near location known as Diamond Rocks
info: A sea monster spotted several times during the nineteenth century was reported to have a head like a horse, a mane of seaweed, and a large body which was hidden under the water.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Ambush
info: For years after an ambush which left many RIC men dead, locals reported hearing the screams of wounded people in the area.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bruckee
info: A demonic badger known as a Bruckee was said to live in this area. One witness who claimed to have observed the creature said it was hairy, brown and had eyes the size of turnips.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bloodied mermaid
location: Killone Lake - Waters of the lake
date: Every forty years, exact date unknown
info: A mermaid who frequented the lake would often steal wine from the crypt beneath the church (or the cellar of Newhall, depending on the storyteller). She was stabbed (or shot) when caught but managed to drag herself back to the lake before dying. The waters are said to turn red with her blood every forty years.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Letherly
info: Letherly was hanged for murder, though this did not prevent him from haunting the home of one of his jurors. The phantom's neck was said to be twisted from the hangman's rope, and it was not long before the family called upon an exorcist to rid themselves of the repulsive ghost.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Donn Dumhach
info: The fairy king known as Donn Dumhach was once believed to live amongst the sandhills.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Eel
info: Little is known about the legend of the eel depicted in Kilmacreehy Church, other than it feasted on corpses.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Kilstiveen
info: The town of Kilstiveen was submerged by a giant tidal wave, its inhabitants washed away to drown. The ghost town occasionally is glimpsed by fishermen.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Kilstuitheen
info: A magical kingdom known as Kilstuitheen or Kilstuiffen once existed in the bay before it was consumed by an earthquake. Every seven years the island briefly returns, any witnesses doomed to die before its next reappearance. It is said the island will permanently return when a golden key belonging to the island's chieftain is rediscovered.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Immortality
location: Lisdoonvarna - Unknown cave between Lisdoonvarna and Ennis
info: The waters of a secret cave located between these two places is said to make the old young, although anyone who actively sought to bathe within it was never seen again.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Kilstiffin
info: Kilstiffin (or Kilstapheen) is another one of Ireland's lost islands. It was said that towers from the city could sometimes be spotted emerging from the sea, and that localised storms periodically manifested over the site.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hump
location: Lough Cullaun - Waters of the lough
info: Tony 'Doc' Shiels watched a hump glide through the water, the sighting lasting several seconds.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sleeping City
info: The chieftain of the sunken city, reported to be hidden under the lough, sleeps until needed to win the final battle.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Back Chair
location: Lough Fergus - Cairns on north shore
info: One of the stones was said to take the form of a chair, where people would sit to cure their backache. It was also said that the water of the lough could never boil, could not drown anyone, and it cured cattle of disease.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Brief Visitor
location: Lough Graney - Waters of the Lake
info: Said to resemble a giant eel, this monstrous creature appears only once every seven years.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Not a Banshee?
info: Residents who lived close to the lough reported hearing the wail of a banshee which lasted for several nights. When the cries ceased and no one died, the locals doubted whether the sounds came from a banshee... A little man in green was also spotted in the area. Matching the description of a leprechaun, a witness tried to grab him for his gold, but the little man vanished.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Carrickogunnel
info: Holding a bright lantern to lure passing ships onto the rocks, the repulsive ghost of Carrickogunnel lurks around the castle. The other phantom found here is that of a bride who mysteriously vanished shortly after being married.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Monks and Priests
location: Scattery Island (Inis Cathaig) - Church of St. Mary near the Round Tower
info: A fisherman caught in a storm sought shelter on the island and went to pray at a ruined church. He encountered many monks and priests within the building, although when he closed his eyes and opened them, the figures had vanished, and the church once more appeared ruined.

region: County Clare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fairy Fort
info: While constructing a new runway during the 1950s, the chief engineer was warned that the work would result in the destruction of a fairy fort - the location of the runway was changed, leaving the fort undisturbed.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Swans
info: Eva, daughter of King Bov, turned her stepchildren into swans, believing them to detract her husband's attention from herself. She instantly regretted her action but was unable to undo the damage. Nine hundred years passed until Christianity reached the shores of Ireland. The power of Christ turned the children back into their former selves, but incredibly aged. They died soon after the transformation and were buried on this site.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mind the Edge
location: Allihies - Cliff near old copper mine, Beara Peninsula
info: After working late one moonless night, a local man returning from the copper mine took a shortcut across a hill. He became lost, and in his confusion fell over the edge of a cliff and died. For many years following the accident, travellers crossing the hill would pause to throw a stone over the edge of the cliff, fearing that failing to carry out the ritual would result in them experiencing the same fatal accident.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Weaver
info: Laden with thread, this phantom was believed to be a tailor who had immorally acquired the thin yarn during his lifetime and was repenting his sins by carrying it upon his back (special thanks to the Churchtown Village Renewal Trust, from their 'The Annals of Churchtown').

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man in White
info: A cyclist was chased by a strange white figure who refused to speak. The cyclist finally stopped pedalling and threw his lamp at the ghost, who immediately vanished. The Channeleen was also home to a phantom woman who wore black (special thanks to the Churchtown Village Renewal Trust, from their 'The Annals of Churchtown').

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Woman in White
info: While camping close to this property, one traveller awoke to see a white female form standing at a gate. He woke one of his friends who also observed the ghostly figure. The following day the travellers moved on and never returned (special thanks to the Churchtown Village Renewal Trust, from their 'The Annals of Churchtown').

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Leprechaun's Shoe
info: A small shoe said to belong to a leprechaun was found near the village by a cow herder. Unfortunately, the man forgot to take the shoe home, and when he went to retrieve it the following day, the shoe had gone.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Young Girl
info: While events started small, with electrical equipment switching itself on and off, it was not too long before the occupants returned from a day out to find the furniture rearranged. Footsteps could be heard, doors opened unaided, and apports came and went. One visitor watched a young girl in old-fashioned clothing enter a room and stand by a fireplace. The family moved away in 2003.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Beiceacan
location: Ballinagree (aka Ballynagree) - Marshland in the area
info: Described as sounding like a calf at slaughter, this entity would prey on lone travellers at night, throwing them into the marsh to drown. One man tracked down Beiceacan, and while wearing spurs, mounted the beast and kicked at its flanks. Beiceacan tossed the man onto the roadside and ran off, never to be see again.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Back Breaking Lady
location: Ballinagree (aka Ballynagree) - Road leading to village
info: A white lady who haunted the road leapt on to the back of a passing horseman, beating the rider with her fists. The man galloped home, unable to shake the phantom from his back. The woman faded away as the man reached his driveway. The following morning the man found himself unable to move and he remained paralysed until dying a few months later.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Brian
info: It was said that a dark room in the castle was home to a ghost named Brian, who would appear on horseback to anyone who ventured into the structure.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Woman
info: A husband and wife encountered a white female phantom standing by the kitchen door, after which they had their bed covers pulled from them by an unseen hand on three consecutive nights.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Killer Woman
location: Ballingeary - Road towards Droumanallig, 300 metres west of Ballingeary
info: A female phantom began to kill those who failed to answer her riddle 'A candle and a candlestick there is, and you fit a couplet to that'. Local man Michael Creedon banished her after replying 'You ought to have got to heaven in time rather than being a ghost as you are'.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Scott
location: Ballinrea South - Roads around Harbour View
info: Recognisable by his white jacket as Scott, a local man who died twenty years previous, his phantom on horseback who manifested in the early hours of the morning became tolerated by the nearby villagers. Scott's appearances became less and less frequent, before he finally vanished for good.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rocking Virgin Mary
info: Cathy O'Mahony and her mother observed the statue of the Virgin Mary rocking on its heels. The following night they returned with friends who observed the same event. Since this time, tens of thousands of people have visited the shrine in the hope of seeing something.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lofo
info: Nicknamed Lofo by the local population, this black dog would grow to several times its original size if challenged or acknowledged. A group of men returning from a wake fled from the hound in terror after one man tried to kick the creature, only for his foot to pass through the dog.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Moddra-na-Craeuv
location: Ballyandrew - Glen of Croke, which stretched from Saffron Hill to Pinegrove
info: The phantom woman who once appeared here was said to be a Creagh girl who died shortly after her lover was killed by her father. The Moddra-na-Craeuv, also known as the dog of the Creaghs, also haunts the area.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Vanishing Island
info: Local fishermen awoke to see a strange new island out to sea, covered with trees and rocks. As dozens climbed into their boats and set off towards it, the island faded from view.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Great Fish
location: Ballycotton - Somewhere between Ballycotton and Old Head of Kinsale
info: A fishing vessel reported being attacked by a dark fish the size of a whale. The fish rammed the boat several times, only ceasing the assault when the captain ordered the engines to be killed; after half an hour, the fish disappeared.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: John the Baptist
info: A rock near the well was said to be the head of John the Baptist, which slowly turned to stone and was weathered by the elements over time.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Killed Animals
info: The family living on the farm tolerated the poltergeist-like entity which shared their home, which would blow on embers in the fireplace and puff on a pipe. One morning the family awoke and found every animal on their farm dead; blaming the entity, the family moved away.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bagpipers
info: The fort in this field was home to four fairy bagpipers dressed in red.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Woman
location: Ballygarvan - Small bridge over a stream
info: A small bridge over a stream near Ballygarvan was home to a white woman. After appearing to one man who fell critically ill the following day, a priest went to the site and banished her.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Skull
info: A skull discovered in this mansion was quickly linked to the 'ghostly' sounds occasionally heard in the area. Police said the skull was smooth, which indicated regular handling, and was likely to have belonged to a former doctor who lived in the building in the 1800s.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mary
info: After having a vision of the Virgin Mary, a farmer converted part of his farm into a shrine which he named House of Mercy.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Former Students
info: After numerous stakeouts, CPI (Cork Paranormal Investigators) are convinced that this disused college is home to several entities, including a priest, a young boy and four teachers. The sound of laughing children and the ringing of a bell are just a few of the incidents reported.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Gobhnet
location: Ballyvourney - St. Gobnait's Well (still present) and area surrounding
info: Gobhnet (or Gobnait) was a nun who built an oratory on the site where she stumbled upon nine white deer. She kept bees that doubled as her protectors, chasing away thieves. The well on the site is still a site of pilgrimage, who tend to visit on 11 February.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lynx
info: A large cat seen as it stepped in front of a car was later identified as a lynx.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: U-28 Creature
location: Baltimore - 17 km south west of Fastnet Rock
info: Commander of the U-28, Freiherr George G von Forstner claimed that after torpedoing the steamer Iberian, the ship sank and exploded, throwing a huge animal out from the sea. The creature was described as resembling a sixty foot long crocodile, with four large webbed feet, a long, pointed tail and a pointed head.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Thrown Stone
info: Ireland's most southerly point, Fastnet Rock was thrown into position by a giant from Mount Gabriel (Schull).

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Money Stone
info: A rock in the centre of the road was known locally as the Money Stone and according to legend was used to mark the location of buried treasure. People had tried to dig up the hoard but were always scared off by a supernatural presence.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Woman on Horseback
info: A phantom woman on a white horse once rode around this area. She is said to have given local man Owen Kelly a lift after he failed to recognise her as a spirit - after riding around in circles and crossing the river three times she vanished, leaving Owen by the fence of his farmland.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Presence
info: A comforting presence is reported to felt in the nursery.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shape Changers
info: The mermaids said to live in this area would be capable of changing their shape as they came on to land. They would also be seen sitting on the rocks playing harps.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Animal Sickness
location: Bantry - Farm near old Danish fort
info: A local story claimed that any disturbance to the fort would result in livestock death, although the farmer's wife disbelieved the tales and dug out an old well on the site. Cows soon fell ill, and calves died. The warning heeded, the woman filled in the well, and as the last stone put in place, a dreadful, disembodied laugh could be heard. The sick cows recovered.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Cloaked Figure
info: Two friends playing in the area observed a tall figure wearing a white cloak moving towards them. The figure had its head bowed, was slightly transparent, and moved in a rocking motion.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fear Gortach
info: People who walk across a patch of Fear Gortach (hungry grass) are said to become insatiably hungry. The grass is thought to be either created by fairies upset at a person's lack of generosity, or cursed by the Fear Gorta, the hungry man, an unshriven corpse who walks the land. The hill here was said to have several patches of the hungry grass.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lights
info: Lights were said to move around the streets at night, and families who had suffered a bereavement would hear footsteps for a few days after death.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Moreno
info: Moreno was a Spanish bard who killed Dion, an Irish bard, in self-defence. However, Dion was well-liked, and one of his followers poisoned Moreno. The Spaniard's ghost is now said to sing on moonlit nights in his mother tongue. The castle is also reputed to be haunted by Lady Margaret Hodnett, described as 'faceless' by some.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Moving Well
location: Berrings - Stoney Pew Line Well (no longer visible?)
info: The Stoney Pew Line Well was considered a holy well and was said to have once been in the parish of Donoughmore. A local woman with no respect for religion went to wash four potatoes in its waters, so the well arose and moved itself four miles to Berrings.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man at the Window
info: Echo Ghosthunters reported seeing a man by a window in the castle, but later found out there was no stairs leading to that spot. EVP was also recorded in another location.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Gift of Oratory
info: Many still kiss this stone in the hope that it will aid them with their public speaking and eloquence. Some believe the stone came from the Middle East and was the pillow of Jacob, while others say it was a gift to Cormac MacCarthy after he saved a witch from drowning.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Little Man
info: Farmer Mick Purcell was forced to take his cow to Cork to sell. While on the road Purcell met a little man and swopped the cow for a small bottle. Understandably, returning home with a bottle instead of money upset Purcell's wife, until he opened it - out sprang two figures which covered the table with gold and silver dishes.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bunworth's Banshee
info: As local rector Charles Bunworth lay dying in his room, a helper who was sent for medicine in a nearby town encountered a wailing woman who informed him Bunworth would die. Bunworth hung on for several days, with wailing and the clapping of hands entering his bedroom window from below. Men who investigated the sounds could see nothing. The sounds stopped as soon as Bunworth died.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Teleporting Goats
date: Early 2000s, for a five year period
info: A goat keeper on the island engaged the Ghost Eire team to investigate why three young goats would move between two pens separated by two six-foot walls, on six different nights. The goat keeper speculated it may have been fairies, upset that he had placed an iron roof on the goat shed.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Thick Mist
info: A group of friends in the woods at dusk reported a thick mist that quickly descended the area. Footsteps and other noises surrounded them as they ran towards the car park. As they ran clear of the woods, the mist lifted, and silence returned once more.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strange Creature
info: A large animal was said to have made this location its home. Although no description of the creature was properly given, it was said to have been large and hunted for food on land. Local men tried to capture the beast but were unable to do so. After several years, the creature left the area, thought to have gone out to sea.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Powerful Dog
info: Said to have made its home in the ruins of a big house, this hound left its dwelling at midnight. Most witnesses were said to have been drunk men, although on one occasion several sober gentlemen chased the creature and had it cornered - the dog vanished in front of their eyes.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dotty Clotty
info: While visiting the family, Uncle Lindsay awoke one morning to see a phantom woman dressed in an old fashioned blue gown standing next to his bed. The family later told him the ghost was that of Lady Clotilda, nicknamed Dotty Clotty.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lord
location: Castlefreke (aka Rathbarry) - Area known as Kennel Field, connected to the castle
date: July, between 17:00h and 18:00h (reoccurring), last seen early twentieth century
info: A gardener for the family claimed to have witnessed the ghost of a former lord wearing riding gear. The ghost would stand motionless for a hour before vanishing.

region: County Cork Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Begging Boy
info: This sad little figure is said to move around begging for his life to be saved. He was murdered by a former owner of the castle for misbehaving.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady Ena
info: A visitor noticed a ghostly woman dressed in a white blouse and long skirt walking from the beach. When talking about the sighting with locals, they believed the figure to have been Lady Ena who once owned the Ards Estate. A lane in the area may also be home to a phantom man killed by the Whiteboys organisation.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Piper Piping
location: Ballintra - Cave system known as Pullans
info: The sound of pipes echoes throughout this cave structure on certain nights, as the ghost of a piper tries to find his way out.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Escape
info: A local newspaper reported that the occupiers of a house along here fled to escape a haunting presence. As a side note, there once stood a fairy well near this site.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Green Lady
info: This old garrison building was said to be haunted by a green lady, though little more is known about her.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Vanishing Hitchhiker
location: Barnesmore Gap - Castlederg junction / bridge area
info: The vanishing hitchhiker in this story takes the form of a young woman who jumps into any car that stops on dark and rainy nights. One story states she entered a taxi passing this way; the car became extremely cold and after nearing a section of road, the woman said, 'Stop here. This is where I died', before vanishing.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Horse
info: Four friends quad biking along the cliffs at night were forced to brake when a ghostly white horse appeared and reared up. The horse vanished, but they friends realised that the cliff path had come to an end; if the phantom horse had not appeared, they would have driven over the edge.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Figures
location: Buncrana - Swan Park and O'Doherty's Keep area
info: Anglers and photographers visiting the area have spotted strange figures near the ruined keep and bridge. One witness watched a ghostly man near the building for several seconds until it disappeared.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fight
location: Bundoran - Close to an unidentified stream in the area
info: The local giant fought another giant who wandered into his land. The local giant managed to kill the newcomer, who, it transpired, was his son.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fairy Bridges
info: It was said that the Fair Folk danced upon the Fairy Bridges, which are actually naturally formed sea stacks. There is also another formation close by known as the Wishing Chair.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Young Woman
location: Burt - Lough Swilly close to Burt Castle
info: A phantom woman throws herself into Lough Swilly and vanishes as nearby swans cry out. The father of the woman's unborn child, who lived at Burt Castle, had refused to help her, although he was later murdered by a member of the woman's family.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Eaten Calves
info: After two calves found half eaten, fears were expressed that a large cat was on the loose in the area. A local RSPCA inspector said it was unlikely that a dog would be able to cause so much damage to the dead animals.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady in Blue
info: A priest at the bottom of the friary's staircase spotted a ghostly lady dressed in blue standing at the top. Another phantom woman, this time dressed in white, may haunt the path leading to the beach. Finally, one story places the ghost of a man here, killed by the Whiteboys organisation.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Woman in Headscarf
info: In 1925 a freak gust of wind blew a train over the edge of the viaduct resulting in the deaths of four people. Since that date, there have been reports of a woman dressed in 1920s clothing and wearing a headscarf. Prior to the accident, an old man thought to have been a worker killed while building the line would be seen walking along the tracks, while on the day of the accident, the same figure appeared to a Kathleen McGinley while she walked to catch the train; the man warned her against travelling and Kathleen cancelled her trip.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Blue Lady
info: The appearance of a phantom woman in blue was said to be so common that she appeared every night. After a team of friars intervened, the ghost was never seen again.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Home
info: This scenic route, popular with walkers, is said to be home to fairies.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Thrown Stone
location: Crolly - The Large Rock Of The Foxes Leap, aka Crolly Stone
info: Fionn Mac Cumhaill threw this large boulder during the pursuit of Diarmuid and Grainne but missed his targets. It is said to grant a wish if three small stones can be successfully thrown on top of it. Another legend says the boulder will roll if the most beautiful maiden in the all the land stands in its shadow.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Darrie Loughlin
location: Derryveagh Mountains - Area around Lough Dheerig (possibly Lough Derg?)
info: Around eighteen months after his death, Darrie Loughlin's ghost started to appear in the area, riding a white horse towards the lough.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Blue Light
info: Paranormal activity featured in a few online reviews, with one claiming a blue light hovered over a bed, and another discussing the mild poltergeist activity experienced during the night.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Crossing Man
info: A misty male figure is said to cross an unidentified road here.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Weeping Statue
info: Fourteen people claimed to witness crosses that formed in the sky above the shrine, before the statue became animated and began to weep.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Green Lady
info: This area is reportedly home to a phantom woman in green.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Humped Creature
info: A female witness reported seeing a strange creature with two humps in the lough.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Old Man
location: Fintown - Unidentified house in the area
info: One story states that this house swopped hands several times, each owner intending to renovate the property, but they would be driven off by a ghostly old man who would often be seen sitting in the kitchen.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Red Haired Lady
info: A ghostly lady with red hair with a child occasionally sit on the bridge.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Hungry
info: During the Great Famine, a pot filled with gruel would be placed on the bridge for passersby to eat. Not everyone who walked along the route survived, and a few of the people who starved to death remain.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Captain
location: Gola Roads, Inishinny - Bunbeg, general area
info: After a particularly fierce storm, the body of a boat's captain known to the locals was discovered on the shoreline. His body was taken back to the mainland, though shortly after he briefly appeared in the hamlet, standing in the doorway of a hut.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Forbidden Couple
info: Another location haunted by a pair of star crossed lovers. In this story, the daughter of Earl William fell in love with the son of a family rival. The son was locked up in the castle and starved to death, while the daughter died trying to help the boy escape. Both now haunt the site.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pair of Lovers
info: The daughter of Earl William and the son of Sir Walter Burk fell in love; unfortunately, their parents were mortal enemies. When Earl Williams discovered the relationship, he locked the young man in a tower to starve to death. When Williams' daughter tried to help her lover, she was killed. The pair are now united as spectres.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man in a White Suit
info: A ghostly gentleman wearing a white suit supposedly walked around the site. A screaming woman would also occasionally be heard.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Running Woman
info: A phantom woman runs out in front of cars, vanishing with a thud when hit, leaving no dent on the vehicle nor evidence she ever existed.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Voices
info: A blessing had to be performed on this site after occupants experienced strange noises, cold spots, and unidentified voices. Researchers later discovered a building that had previously stood on the site had been used to home the sick.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Adam Grierson
info: Francis Bradley was twice put on trial for the murder of Adam Grierson, each time the jury unable to agree a verdict. During the third trial, a priest attempted to summon the ghost of Grierson; as he called for the ghost to come, the sky darkened and the horses outside could be heard to whinny. The judge demanded the priest to cease, and the sky returned to normal. The third jury also failed to reach a verdict. More recently, items are reputed to move around the site and nightwatchmen are wary.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dancing Fairies
location: Lough Derg - Exact location not known
info: A group of children encountered between eight and ten fairies dancing to music. One of the little people charged towards the children, striking one girl with a plant - the children ran home, and the girl who was hit later collapsed, only waking when a priest visited her.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rowing Boat
location: Lough Derg - Waters of the lough
info: A phantom rowing boat was said to haunt this body of water, although no crew could ever be seen within. It would be accompanied with music and voices.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Suileach
location: Lough Swilly - Waters of the lough
info: Suileach was a huge creature with many eyes and spread terror throughout the county. The creature is thought to have been killed by Saint Colum Cuille in the sixth century.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Unknown Creature
location: Lough Waskel - Waters of the lough
info: A fisherman is said to have caught a strange brown creature covered in creamy blotches here.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Blue Figure
info: This property featured in several media outlets in 2021 when occupant Emma Louise Tully said she had been physically attacked by ghosts. Tully had also encountered a protective blue misty figure, thought to be Sara Waller who was murdered on the site.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Siobhan Neill
info: Siobhan, daughter of the clan's leader, was found dead by the river. People claimed she had died while learning to swim, although others said she had been murdered for trying to escape an arranged marriage. Regardless, Siobhan's ghost haunts the area.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Woman
info: After a tall ghostly white woman began to walk the streets at night, it was reported many residents refused to leave their homes after dark.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Length of Life
info: This well was said to inform people how much longer they had to live. If someone looked into it and the water bubbled and overflowed, they had a long life ahead of them. However, if the water level sank lower, then the end was nigh.

region: County Donegal Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Faceless Woman
info: A dark-haired, faceless figure dressed in white would patrol the area and was blamed for the death of a servant after he quit and took his own life.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Waiting Lady
location: Balbriggan - Ardgillan Castle, bridge in garden over railway known as The Lady's Stairs
info: This phantom woman is said to be waiting for her husband to return. He was a keen swimming, but drowned one night, leaving his wife on the bridge awaiting his return. One version of the story says that whoever sees the ghost on Halloween will be picked up and thrown into the ocean.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Green Cat
info: A phantom cat, green in colour, was reported to haunt this town.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Yellow Eyed Dog
info: A witness watched a large black dog with yellow eyes cover eighteen metres in just three strides. Over the following two months the witness lost two members of their family.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Apologise to the Tree
info: If the fairy tree found near the course is hit by an errant golf ball, the player is advised to apologise to avoid the wrath of the little people. Even if not struck, it is said that golfers nod at the tree as they pass. Just in case.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Nun
location: Blanchardstown - Former monastery converted into a home
date: Late nineteenth or early twentieth century
info: A servant was said to have encountered a phantom nun within this house. Footsteps would also be heard, while doors would open themselves at night.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coach and Four
location: Clondalkin - Newlands House, currently part of the Newlands Golf Club
info: Newlands was once owned by Arthur Wolfe, Chief Justice of Ireland; the ghostly coach is said to follow the route it once took, taking Arthur's body away from his home.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mr Cobbe
info: The ghostly Mr Cobbe drives his coach drawn by six headless horses close to the park. One version of the story says he is no longer seen, but the phantom's presence is marked by the sound of a gate opening and shutting.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Butcher
info: Unease spread amongst workmen in the process of demolishing the house after they spotted a spectral butcher moving around the rooms. The ghost had previously been reported in two other houses along the road which had already been knocked down.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Woman
info: Now thought to have been exorcised, this phantom woman wearing old fashioned clothing was seen by neighbours looking in through the window.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
info: Starting in the 1920s, and lasting for a period of around thirty years, occupants in number 7 reported hearing shoeless footsteps which traversed the rooms and corridors. Number 8 was haunted by a man seen standing by the fireplace.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shadows
info: Investigated by GhostEire, the site located in a former red light district is home to shadowy people and an unidentified voice picked up on recording equipment.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shaking
location: Dublin - Ardee House (demolished mid twentieth century)
info: A bedroom in this property was considered particularly haunted, with occupants being violently shaken awake.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Archdeacon Bulkeley?
location: Dublin - Area around Old Bawn Road and the Dodder
info: Said to either be driven by or containing Archdeacon Bulkeley, a coach drawn by six headless horses containing two passengers together with two footmen, drives through this area of Dublin. Anyone who spots the coach is said to die within 366 days.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Robert Emmet
info: Rebel leader Robert Emmet is said to have used the Brazen Head for meetings until executed in 1803. His ghost is said to remain, still on the lookout for enemies.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lord Norbury
info: The otherworldly black hound which stalks the area is said to be the ghost of Lord Norbury, a harsh judge renowned for his overuse of the hangman's noose.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Old Lady
info: A cyclist riding along the canal witnessed a glowing elderly woman in white with long hair dancing with a young man. The man wore a seventeenth or eighteenth century military uniform and looked 'normal', unlike the woman who also hummed a tune. The cyclist did not stop.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: James Clarence Mangan
location: Dublin - Castle Inn, Lord Edward Street
info: Mangan was born in this building and is said to periodically return, his presence bringing an overwhelming depression to the site.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shuffling Feet
info: One guest at the hotel claimed to hear footsteps in his room at night. The man also said that his shower had turned itself on and his TV flicked channels over at will...

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Soldier
info: A security guard on the night shift spotted a man resembling a soldier wearing grey on the station's CCTV. The guard went to investigate the disused platform where the figure had been seen and found no one there.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Matching Band
info: During the Easter Rising of 1916, the family and staff at Corkagh House heard a band playing and the sound of marching feet heading towards the house. Those present thought they would be attacked but the sounds suddenly stopped and nothing could be seen. More recently, the park is reputedly home to a headless horseman and/or the sound of horses hooves' heard along an area known as the 'Devils Passageway'.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Screams of the Drowning
location: Dublin - Deey Bridge and canal lock
info: A passenger boat sunk here in the eighteenth century; many of the occupants drowned, and their psychic screams continue to this day.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Eleanora
info: Eleanora's new husband fought her true love, with both men dying for their injuries. After Eleanora died (of either suicide or exposure), her ghost began haunting her home.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Robert Emmet
info: Patrick F. Byrne wrote that the ghost of Emmet could be observed in the garden, although one of Byrne's friends proved the 'ghost' was only a shadow caused by a gate post.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Invaders
info: Men who tried to invade the castle were executed on site and their headless remains buried within the grounds. Sometimes their spirits are said to wander.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Knock on Wood
location: Dublin - Fishamble Street Theatre (no longer standing)
info: The Green Room of this former theatre was haunted by phantom rapping, which always started at the same time each evening and lasted exactly fifteen minutes.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Faceless Woman
location: Dublin - Flat near the North Circular Road
info: Two friends chatting outside a flat spotted an old woman walking along the road, pausing every so often to pick up scraps of rubbish. The friends commented on how terrible it was to see the woman alone in that state and continued to watch as she climbed some stairs to the house on the opposite side of the road. The woman turned to face the friends, who then realised the woman's face was brightly glowing, and her legs and hands were also illuminated. The glowing woman then turned her back and vanished.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady Gregory
location: Dublin - Former Abbey Theatre (National Theatre of Ireland) (demolished 1960)
info: Lady Gregory took the lead in finding the funds to build the theatre, and had a favourite chair in the auditorium. After Gregory's death, anyone who sat in the chair would feel something pushing against them.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strange Presence
info: A cleaner would feel a strange presence in the showers on the third floor, which would build until the cleaner could sense someone standing behind them. Upon turning, no one would be there, but the sensation would start to build again. The cleaner would later discover another person who worked at the site also felt the same presence and, seriously unnerved by the fear it created, left after a week.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Boyd's Dog Returns
info: The ghost of a Newfoundland dog sometimes appears at the grave of John McNeill Boyd. After Boyd drowned, the dog refused to leave his master's grave and slowly starved to death. The loyal hound is still seen both in the area and at St Patrick's Cathedral.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Buck Whaley
location: Dublin - St Stephen's Green, leading to Cuffe Street
info: Pacing along the road, Whaley's shade is said to follow the well-travelled route he took while living.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Airman
location: Dublin - Temple Theatre Nightclub (no longer operating) (formally St George's church)
info: A spokesperson for the nightclub claimed that P Diddy had encountered a ghostly airman in the nightclub, which had been a church. Another report said the nightclub, when not open to the public, was also home to the sounds of a church organ being played, the notes punctuated by bouts of coughing.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shadows
info: Though not officially used for many years, visitors to the site at night report dancing shadows in and around the former hunting lodge.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Larry the Wax
info: The phantom cobbler known as Larry the Wax would vanish when told to 'go to hell'.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Opening Door
location: Dublin - Tivoli Variety Theatre (closed 1930), Burgh Quay
info: A door at the theatre would always be found open - the ghost of a chorus girl who took her own life would be blamed.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady Reid
location: Dublin - Town house in Fitzwilliam Square
info: This phantom woman has terrorised many visitors to the house who have tried to spend the night in the guest bedroom.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Corney
location: Dublin - Unknown house near St Stephen's Green
info: Most of Corney's antics resembled classic poltergeist activity (hiding crockery and cutlery, pinching people as they lay in bed), though he did manifest to a young boy who described him as a naked old man. The haunting became so well known locally that the owners had a very hard time trying to sell the house.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Gammon
info: The widow Gammon is said to have informed Cromwell's men that monks were hiding in this area. After her death, the widow's ghost returned to the area, one witness claiming that the phantom had touched his neck, leaving a burn.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lord Luttrell
info: A man reported being followed by a white figure along the street that he believed to be Lord Luttrell, the so-called 'King of Hell', who was killed along the street in 1717.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lilac Balls of Light
info: Some locals say that these balls of light, lilac in colour, are fairies; others say they are the manifestation of a lady who lost her way in a bad snowstorm in the middle ages and consequently died - she now tries to prevent her fate from happening to others.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Devil in Disguise
location: Dublin - Grand canal near Harcourt Bridge (aka Rialto Bridge)
info: The devil would take the form of a black dog and stalk the area around the bridge.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Cross at the Window
location: Dublin - Iveagh House, St Stephen's Green
info: A cross would once manifest upon a windowpane facing the square, visible to those walking by the property. It is reported that crowds would gather hoping to see the unearthly crucifix.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rolling Apple
info: CCTV footage released on YouTube appears to show an apple falling from a fruit stall and rolling backwards and forwards on the floor, as if being pushed between two unseen figures.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Flying Brandy
location: Dublin - John Mulligan's public house, Poolbeg Street
info: One barman watched a bottle of brandy fly off the shelf, while other staff have reported knocking and footsteps in empty parts of the pub. A figure has also been reported walking by the bar when the pub is closed.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Buck Jones
info: Riding headless on the back of a white horse, this phantom is named as Buck Jones, former City Sheriff (though the man died in a debtor's prison).

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
location: Dublin - Kilmainham Gaol (former prison, now a museum)
info: While being renovated, workers in this old gaol reported hearing strange footsteps. Other visitors have reported the feeling of being watched.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Jangling
info: The area where an old woman was murdered by a tramp was haunted by a strange jangling sound. Two sisters who heard the jangling were hit by a blast of air as it passed them.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Girl with Curly Hair
info: After Lord Mayor Naoise O Muiri's four year old daughter reported seeing a girl with dark curly hair watching television, he told the local press that the building was haunted.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pat Doyle
info: Doyle attempted to escape from the Marshalsea prison but fell from a roof and died. His ghost could be seen balancing of a wall for several years after his death.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Archbishop Narcissus Marsh
info: The wraithy Archbishop still looks through the books and manuscripts which line the library's shelves. One legend says he is searching for a lost letter, hidden within the pages of an unknown volume.

region: County Dublin Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sean Treacy
location: Dublin - Mater Private Nursing Hospital (no longer standing?)
info: Sean appeared to his friend Dan Breen as he lay in hospital - both were involved in a gun fight with the British, though Sean died of his wounds some hours before visiting Dan.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Lady
info: Reportedly 'benign', this phantom white lady is said to have been a member of the ffrench family who was held prisoner in the Old Tower to ensure she did not escape her arranged marriage.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Short Men in Green
location: Aran Island - Exact location not known
info: A fifteen year old boy spotted two figures sea fishing, each just over a metre tall, dressed in green and wearing brown shoes. The figures chattered to each other in Irish before jumping up and vanishing. One of the figures left a small pipe behind which the witness took, although it later disappeared when 'safely' locked away.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mantelpiece
info: The ghost of a tall man attached itself to the mantelpiece which was in this house - when a stoneworker took the piece away, the ghost followed both it and him and began to haunt his workshop. Items were thrown around, and strange fiddling could be heard at night. It is unclear whether the new owner returned the mantelpiece or smashed it up.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Woman with a Lamp
info: While playing Geocaching, two friends met an older lady with a lamp walking through the woods. Sharing the story once they arrived home, they discovered a family member had also met the older lady around 35 years previous. A legend says that a ghostly lady walks the area, looking for her son who had died.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Screaming
location: Aughrim - Site of Battle of Aughrim
info: The battle, fought in 1691, is said to have been the most brutal on UK soil, with up to seven thousand people killed. Folklore says that the screams of dying soldiers can still be heard in the area.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Lady
info: A phantom white lady named as Lady Clancarty haunts the halls, which is also home to a bloodstained stone which can never be removed, even after scrubbing.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Knocking Girl
info: An unknown young girl has sometimes been seen standing by an upstairs window in the ruined house. There are reports of strange, loud bangs which drift from the empty building.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: First Irish Case?
info: The BBC reported that Dr Ciaran McLoughlin, West Galway coroner, had recorded a verdict of spontaneous combustion in a case he had investigated. The body of Michael Faherty had been found in his living room, totally burnt, although damage to the rest of the room was minimal.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Trotting Dog
info: Potentially last seen by a cyclist, the black dog which haunted this area would vanish into thin air as witnesses looked on.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bear-faced Man
location: Ballymacward - Lane near Woodlawn railway station
info: Two people walking home after leaving the station heard groaning coming from over a wall. One climbed up to have a look and observed a creature with a man's body but with the head of a bear. The witness tried to speak to the strange creature, but it told him 'don't speak to me' before wandering off.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Large Eel
location: Ballynahinch - Bridge near to Ballynahinch Castle
info: A long eel-like creature remained stuck under this bridge for two days.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Christopher St George
info: Christopher came from a strongly Protestant family but fell in love with and married a Catholic woman. His family immediately disowned him, his ghost a testament to his protests of being unfairly treated.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Poor
info: Stories say the castle was a place for people to gather during the Great Famine, and those who died remained on the site.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Loathsome Creature
info: After spotting this strange water creature, one of the witnesses had nightmares for weeks after the event and refused to return alone to the lake. She said the creature was long and black, with smooth skin and a head like a shark.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Morby
info: A friendly older man wearing a black hat has been named as Morby, a former gardener who still returns to the gardens post-mortem.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Horned Eel
info: A family watched this creature, almost four metres long, swimming around the lake. It was described as dark and long without hair or eyes, and possessed two horns at the top of the head.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strangler
info: This house is thought to be haunted by the ghost of a man who strangled himself with bare hands. Doors are reported to open and close unaided, while figures have been seen reflected in mirrors. One phantom on the site is named as 'Old Mrs Gogarty', and little is known about the ghostly man dressed in tweed.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Figure in the Window
info: A former owner of the house bricked up an upstairs window after repeatedly seeing a figure staring down at him when his home should have been empty.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Murdered Pirates
info: Sometimes one can see a ghostly pirate ship drop anchor just off the coast; the battle scarred sailors use smaller boats to row to the castle where they carry chests and sacks of gold and jewels into the ruined structure.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Soldier
info: An unknown amount of gold hidden somewhere in this area is guarded by a ghostly soldier.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pig Fish
info: A sea monster caught by a fishing crew was seen by thousands of people. The creature was described as nine and a half feet (2.9 metres) long, weighed 136 kilograms and had silvery skin. The head had a long pig-like snout, cow-like eyes, and two rows of teeth, each tooth around two inches (5 centimetres) in length. The creature also had an underbelly of sharp thorns. The Dublin Museum later identified the creature as a bramble shark.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Nun
location: Galway - Hole in the Wall public house
info: The ghost of a nun has been seen descending the staircase before vanishing.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Ellen
info: Ellen, or Eleanor, was the daughter of Lord Blake and died in a mysterious fire together with two maids. Eleanor's presence is reputed to remain.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Faceless Nun
location: Galway - Mick Lally Theatre, and nearby roads
info: The faceless nun which walks the area may have been heard by a lone worker in the theatre, although he did not hang around to find to confirm the theory.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tall Man
location: Galway - Newcastle area (possibly neighbourhood known as Granville)
info: Two men walking in the evening encountered a dark human-like shape, some nine foot (2.74 metres) in height. The figure vanished as it moved closer, only to reappear further down the road. The following night, a party armed with sticks and pistols tried to find the entity. They succeeded, although as one man took aim with his revolver, he dropped the weapon and fainted. The entity vanished once again and never returned.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Moving Toys
info: A haunting presence made itself known in this house shortly after the birth of a girl. Unexplained footsteps and crying could be heard, toys rearranged, items would fall from the walls, and a jug shattered after being thrown on the staircase. Although frightening, family members believed the entity was protecting the newborn. The family eventually moved out and a priest visited to bless the rooms.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: WB Yeats
info: Yeats treated this building as home away from home and is believed to still reside here. Several of the rooms are also haunted by the ghosts of children.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Third Floor Ghost
info: This shop enjoyed a brief surge in online publicity when some news outlets showed a poster on display which stated, 'Ouija boards and seances are not allowed to be performed in this shop'. It was reported that the manager believed the third floor to be haunted and did not want anyone attracting more ghosts.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Claddagh Nun?
info: An image from photographer Jonathan Curran showed what looked like a nun standing along the Long Walk at Claddagh, although the woman may just be a living person who popped up at the wrong time...

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Murdered Woman
info: Thousands of people were reported to have stood outside this house after the ghost of a woman appeared in a window. She had been murdered by her husband fifteen years previous and had recently manifested to a couple walking to church, asking them to say a prayer for her.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rhino-Like Creature
location: Glinsk - Lough Dubh, aka Black's Lake, between Glinsk and Roscommon
info: A cow-sized creature was hooked by a man and his son out fishing along the river - the monster emerged from the water after the younger of the two snagged it with his hook. The strange beast was described as having short stumpy legs, small ears, and a single horn protruding from its nose.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Water Horse
info: The lake is said to be home of a mysterious water monster resembling a horse.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Norman
location: Gort - Islandmore Castle (also known as Thoor Ballylee)
info: W B Yeats believed his summer home to be shared by a ghost of a Norman soldier, although a photograph taken 1989 shows a shadowy child.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Giant Eel
info: At least one swimmer in the Lough has been chased by a wriggling water monster, named by locals as a giant eel.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Monk
info: A phantom monk that haunts a staircase creates cold spots and occasionally appears on photographs. Ghosthunters visiting the site may have also photographed a ghostly lady.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Large Swimming Creature
location: Lough Auna - Waters of the lough
info: A local farmer spotted a grey creature in the lough during the sixties, while in 1969 Royal Netherlands Air Force Commodore Kort claimed to have witnessed a life form with a pointed back swimming through the water.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Partying
info: The echo of a party, complete with music and laughter, can be heard from the building, though some reports say the celebrations end with screams and cries for help.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sad Old Man
location: Maam Cross - Old dirt road running along a hill
info: This phantom stands on a sharp bend in the road - cars have passed straight through him.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Thrown Cutlery
info: Invisible hands threw cutlery from the dining table and, on another occasion, a group of black-clad people entered the house before disappearing through a wall.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Butler
info: After taking his own life, the butler took to frequently appearing in the castle. A priest relocated the phantom to the garden, where the ghost worked to keep nighttime intruders away.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tapping
info: Reputed to be haunted, other than tapping on the windows, the exact details of the non-threatening ghost that lurks here are not clear.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rolling Head
info: A phantom head reputedly rolls around the floor and the sounds of someone choaking occasionally fill the air. It is also claimed a former gamekeeper haunts the site.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rachel
info: Rachel Ward, Countess of Dudley, drowned in the waters a short distance from the house in 1920. Although quiet now, the countess's phantom haunted the house for many years.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fairy Battle
location: Taum - Cnoc Meadha, aka Knockmagha, Knockma, or Knock Ma (hill)
info: It was said that fairies fought openly above the skies of this hill during the potato famine. The hill is also said to be the burial place of Finnbheara, king of the Connacht fairies.

region: County Galway Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bell
location: Tynagh - Pallas Estate (no longer standing) and Castle
info: The estate homed two ghosts, one a travelling woman and the other a ghostly carriage drawn by four horses which pulled up to the front door. The latter was banished by a Bishop armed with holy water. A bell would be heard to ring from the castle after a family member died.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Funeral Procession
info: After a non-local man was buried in this graveyard, the ghosts of his ancestors were seen walking slowly towards his grave.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Danish Captain
info: This ghost was once a well-treated prisoner in the castle, who died trying to protect the building from a large scale robbery.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rumoured Entity
info: Prior to renovation, the site had a reputation as being home to a ghost, although the exact details are not known and it is now said the phantom is quiet.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Humming Train
info: A sound likened to that of a train has been said to wake locals in the early hours of the morning, even though the closest rail tracks are 15 kilometres away. The humming sound has been reported to be so loud that houses vibrate.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Kerry Carabuncle
location: Brandon - Mount Brandon - Lough  Veagh and/or Lough Geal
info: This lake is home to a mythical snake-like beast which is covered in jewels and gold. The monster is said only to appear once every seven years.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dying Cattle
location: Brosna - Former croft at Knockeencreen (currently a cattle shed?)
info: A man whose cattle were dying mysteriously was informed by a passing gypsy that his home was blocking a fairy path, and by leaving the doors open at night, the fairies could pass happily pass through. The man did so, and the deaths stopped.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Earless Dog
info: The ghostly, earless dog that haunted this area was supposed to emerge from the castle's moat at night before wandering off to hunt rabbits.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Death Coach
info: As the owner of the house lay dying, the other family members around his bed heard a horse drawn coach pull up outside the house. Believing it to be the doctor, they rushed downstairs, but nothing could be seen on the gravel driveway. The owner died soon after.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Warning
info: A fishing vessel crewed by eleven men sank on shallow rocks, the accident killing two. Some of the survivors claimed they had heard a disembodied voice warning them not to embark, and then just before the accident, they heard laughter and other noises, but could not see anything in the darkness of night.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Cow Protectors
location: Dingle - Fairy fort just outside of town
info: Farmer Hanafin left a cow unmilked on his land to ensure the local fairies could feed their children. When Hanafin fell into financial difficulty and the bailiffs tried to take his cattle as payment, the fairies fought back; the bailiffs were almost killed by an unseen force, and the cattle ran back to pasture.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Crying Banshee
info: A family named Hussey were filled with dread when they heard the wailing of the banshee outside their home. However, the banshee stopped crying and told them that she would never warn 'hoarding traders' of impending death. Sure enough, the following day the family discovered another man by the name of Hussey in the town had died.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Screams of Spanish Soldiers
info: Over eight hundred Spanish soldiers landed here in 1580, overrunning an English garrison. Spanish reinforcements failed to come, however, and their victory was short lived when more English troops arrived. The Spaniards surrendered, but most were immediately put to death by the enraged English. Their death throes echo around the area on the anniversary of their defeat.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sheriff
info: The ruins of this castle were reputedly home to the ghost of a former Kerry sheriff.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Ghost Whisperer
info: Owner Mike Robertson made the local press after he offered a reward of 50k to anyone who could tame the three ghosts which haunted his property, thought to a one woman and two men. The ghosts were blamed for the strange sounds which were heard after dark.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mermaid?
info: A mermaid which was spotted several times in this area was described as a 'normal' woman, leading one to conclude that maybe she was..?

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Gwendolyn Herbert
info: Gwendolyn, the daughter of the first owner of the property, is said to remain here and has been spotted on the main staircase.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Staircase Lurker
info: The phantom said to have been heard on the staircase would appear to have been banished after a Mass was performed on the site.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Vanishing Girl
location: Killarney - Derrycunnihy Church and surrounding area
info: A variation on the vanishing hitchhiker story has the ghostly white woman supposed to haunt this church sometimes appear in the back seat of passing cars. The stories say she died in an accident close to the church while cycling home.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: French Girl
info: The GhostEire team recorded an EVP that they identified as a girl speaking French.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sarah Reynolds
info: A former servant at Muckross House, it is said that Sarah died in mysterious circumstances after entering a relationship with the owner of the property.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Donal
info: Donal McCarthy Mor founded the nearby Muckross Abbey but has now wandered away and frequents the hotel bar. The site is also reputed to be haunted by a young woman or girl in nineteenth century clothing.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: O'Donoghue
date: 01 May (O'Donoghue, every 7 years) (reoccurring), others on misty nights
info: A warrior by the name of O'Donoghue is said to emerge from the waters of the lake on the back of a white horse once every seven years. Another story has an unidentified figure walking a hound appear on misty nights.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Robed Figure
info: Several people are reported to have seen a robed figure walking around the site, leading to speculation the distillery is haunted by a monk. One of the original owners of the property, constructed in the mid-eighteenth century, was also said to have remained here.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pale Eel-Thing
info: Cryptozoologist Jonathan Downes and his wife spotted a nine-foot (2.74 metre) long, pale eel-like creature swimming in these waters.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bess Stokes
location: Killorglin - Ard na Sidhe Country House
info: Bess Stokes was said to take the form of an older lady in grey, and haunt the gate close to the cottage that she had built.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Prophet
info: While one newspaper reported the site was haunted by a prophet, it is unclear where this story originated. One paranormal group recorded a heavy door opening unaided.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Chair Thrower
location: Listowel - Glanuna Foka, house along Convent Street
info: During one polt outbreak, chairs and other furniture were thrown through the windows. Locals were quickly on the scene but could not find anyone in the house.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pig-like Creature
location: Lough Brin - Water near Moll's Gap
info: This area was visited in 2004 by a Japanese TV crew looking for the monster said to live here. The entity has a similar appearance to a black pig but blowed water from its back like a whale. It was spotted in 1954 by a farmer taking his cattle for milking, while in 1979 two more farmers spotted a black three metre long creature swimming in the waters.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Peist
location: Lough Leane - Waters of the lough
info: This lough is said to be home to a lake monster.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Dogs
location: Meenogahane - Area once known as Laghtnegunbane
info: An area around here was known as 'grave of the white dogs' and thought to be haunted by the creatures.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fairy Forts
location: N22 - Dip in road close to Kerry Way, Curraglass
info: A member of parliament made headlines after he declared a dip in the road, which had cost forty thousand Euros to repair, had been caused by fairies who lived in forts which the road navigated around.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Stomping Boots
location: Skellig Michael - Lighthouse and general area
info: The lighthouse was haunted by cries, bangs, doors which slammed, and the sound of footsteps which crossed the floor as the keepers sat down to eat. The haunting drove two of the keepers away (or drove them insane, depending on the source).

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Washed up
