info: Following a storm, a sea creature (curiously described as a sea orangutan) washed up on the beach. From head to toe, the creature measured 4.14 metres, and when stretched, the creature's arms spanned 3.4 metres. A newspaper said the creature to be 'a frightful looking devil'.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Headless Man
location: Sneem - Blackwater bridge, between village and Kenmare
info: This bridge was the traditional haunt of a headless male figure. One legend says that the headless phantom was attacked by another ghost, although the outcome of the fight is not known.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Former Judge
location: Tarbert - Tarbert Bridewell Courthouse and Jail Museum
info: Prisoners housed at this jail would be subjected to heinous conditions, and are perhaps responsible for the feelings of dread felt here at night. A former judge who condemned many of those prisoners is also thought to remain.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hilda
info: Affectionately named Hilda, this phantom former landlord is reputed to appear on an annual basis.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Millicent Agnes Yielding
info: The Ghost Eire team investigated this site reputedly haunted by Millicent Yielding, killed by a sail and who now stands looking from a window (or possibly not, as sometimes folklore says she is headless). The press reported the team may have made contact with a young woman.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Faces
info: A priest was called in to bless this flat after residents heard sounds from the fireplace and spotted human faces in the walls.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
location: Tralee - Osborne public house (no longer operating)
info: Despite two previous exorcisms, The Osborne remained haunted by footsteps running up the staircase and the sounds of things being thrown around.

region: County Kerry Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mug Ruith
info: Mug Ruith, also known as Mogh Roith, made his home on this island. According to legend, the blind druid of Munster flew a machine known as an 'oared wheel' and drove a chariot that could blind and deafen people.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strange Mist
info: Before a large part of this boggy land was drained, it was renowned for strange shapes, vaguely human in appearance, which appeared at night. One man who walked across the area encountered a strange cloud which enveloped him, filling the poor man with terror, before it drifted off.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Peeping Figure
info: A ghostly figure has been seen peering out a second floor window of the castle. A few critics pointed out that most witnesses have just left public houses and bars at midnight and may not have been in the clearest of minds.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Wizard Earl of Kildare
location: Ballitore - Rath of Mullaghmast (earthworks and forts)
info: The wizard Earl of Kildare reputedly sleeps around this area of forts and standing stones, waking every seven years to ride a horse shod with silver. Some say that while out riding he is accompanied by his men, and that when the horse's silver shoes have worn down, the wizard will banish Ireland's foes from the land.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Band
info: On two different occasions, villagers heard drums, brass, and a cornet being played in the village hall at midnight, although the building would be locked and unlit.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Stable Boy
info: A stable boy, killed after being discovered in the bedroom of the owner's daughter, still walks around the building looking for his former girlfriend. The castle also carries stories about being haunted by a former wizard who once resided there, who remains in a trance under the structure (although another variation of the story says he returns to the castle every seven years riding a white horse with silver shoes). More recently, a groundsman spotted a woman and a child heading running along the avenue towards the castle - the figures suddenly vanished. Shadowy figures and disembodied voices have also been reported.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man in Grey Coat
info: On two occasions, people clearing up after a party could hear eighteenth century music emerge from one room. Folklore says a spectre dressed in a long grey coat is can be heard laughing mockingly. One legend attached to the building has the Devil paying a previous owner a visit - it is unclear whether the hauntings are connected to this event.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Big Eyed Dog
info: The phantom hound with glowing eyes which walked the corridors at night was said by students to be the manifestation of a hanged murderer. The building was also once witness to a Crisis Manifestation, when the ghost of a Marshall appeared to two sisters - they identified him as their brother, who, it was later discovered, was killed in action at the time of the visitation.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Matron
info: During a two day paranormal investigation at this location by NIPRA the group believed they encountered a matron who worked with Tuberculosis patients.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tiny Horses
info: Author Herbie Brennan and a friend visited this site late at night and spotted several small white horses galloping along the earthwork. He described them as being no taller than a cocker spaniel and around 25 in number.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Handsome Jack
info: Colonel John St Leger, aka Handsome Jack once owned this castle while a member of the Hellfire Club. After his sudden death in Madras, he returned to the area, in a coach and four, driven by a headless horseman.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Young Child
location: Kildare - Road outside Clongowes Wood College
info: Several motorists have had to brake sharply to avoid hitting a child who runs out in front of them. The infant always quickly vanishes after the driver stops. The area is also home to a phantom coach which halts at the front gates at midnight.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Drinking Stone
info: This large stone reputedly moves down to a nearby stream to drink every night.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tall Figure
info: The ghostly footsteps heard around the building may be related to the seven-foot tall figure spotted walking through a doorway and heading towards the Phelan Room. A priest may also haunt the site (or may be the same figure).

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Walking Backwards
info: A local piece of folklore claims that walking backwards around the structure twelve times results in the Devil appearing.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Possible Poetry Inspiration
info: Arthur Griffin's poem 'The Thirteenth Lock' may have been inspired by the Lyons Hill's lock, the thirteenth along the Grand Canal, the building of which had displaced an old graveyard.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Projectionist
info: Thought to be a projectionist from the 1940s who fell to his death, this phantom is reputed to turn a particular chair around 180 degrees if he dislikes a production.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Suicidal Student
info: After two students committed suicide in room 2 of the building, and a third leapt from the window after believing an evil spirit was trying to take over his body, someone summoned a priest to spend the night. In the morning the priest was found a gibbering wreck; fear had turned his hair white.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Limping Liam
info: A ghost nicknamed Limping Liam hobbles around this area. One story says the body of an unknown man killed in the Irish Rebellion of 1798 was brought to the town on the back of the cart. The body tumbled off the cart and limped a little way along the road before falling and dying again.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Banshee Cries
info: Richard Mather claimed to have listened to a banshee wail for five minutes sometime after midnight. After the story appeared in the local press, it was suggested had heard a fox.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Soldier
location: Sallins - Soldier's Island (small island at conjunction of the Grand Canal and the Naas)
info: The island is said to take its name from a solider who hanged himself from a tree - his ghost is said to have remained.

region: County Kildare Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Railway Guard
info: This former rail employee walks along the track carrying a lamp. In 1853 an accident between two trains killed sixteen people; an inquiry blamed the guard who had forgotten to attach a lamp at the rear of the train (which would have prevented the collision). To atone, the guardsman forever walks the rails.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man in Black
info: Dressed in 1800s or early 1900s black clothing, a phantom man has been sighted standing beside the roadside bushes.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Miners
info: Local folklore says that phantom miners still walk to the pit.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady with Crutches
location: Kilkenny - Area around St John's Parochial Hall
info: Moving around on crutches, the ghost of a tall lean woman with flowing hair and long coat has been reported around the hall.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bells
info: The old servant bells were said to ring themselves in the early hours of the morning.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sleeping Sentry
info: A guard at the castle once fell asleep while on duty and was thrown from the battlements by his superior officer as punishment. Once a year, his footsteps are heard as he walks around to make amends for his inappropriate actions. A ghostly woman can also be heard as she moves around on a staircase, accompanied by the smell of wildflowers.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Drowned
info: The bridge collapsed in 1763, the accident sending a crowd of people into the river below and many to their deaths. When there is a slight mist over the river, some believe those who drowned can be seen.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady in White
info: This female form is said to occasionally appear on a staircase and in the garden. A legend says this ghost (or perhaps others) ensure that no guest will have a restful night within the castle.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Not Dame Alice Kyteler
location: Kilkenny - Kyteler's Inn public house, Kieran Street
info: Alice Kyteler was accused of witchcraft after the death of her fourth husband in 1325. As the mob approached Kyteler's home, she fled. The angry crowd grabbed Kyteler's maid and executed her instead, possibly unaware of their mistake. The maid is now thought to haunt the site.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dame Alice Kyteler
info: Alice Kyteler was a fourteenth century witch (well, she was tried for witchcraft) who now appears on the stairs close to the western window.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
info: The caretaker of the theatre said in the local media that they had heard footsteps and voices in areas which were empty, and that the ghost would stand in the gantry.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Wolf Men
location: Kingdom of Ossory - Ossory was a sub-kingdom, most of which was in County Kilkenny
info: It was said that men from this kingdom could transform into wolves whenever they pleased. However, while in wolf form their human bodies would be left at home. If moved, the person would be trapped as a wolf for the rest of their life.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lights
info: The abbey has long been said to be home to ghostly lights, which may have been connected to a rumoured secret tunnel. Today the site is said to create mysterious light anomalies on camera.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hurlers
location: Lough Cullen (aka Holly Lake) - Waters of the lough
info: Ghostly hurlers reputedly come out when the moon is full and play on the surface of the lough, shouting until engulfed by the water. After they vanish, a phantom witch (who is credited with creating the lake) appears and cries out, 'An luachair, an luachair!'. Another story told of Lough Cullen claims it is bottomless.

region: County Kilkenny Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coach and Horses
info: Several entities were said to have taken up residence around the castle, including a phantom coach which would arrive outside the front door, an older man seen on the first floor, ringing bells and a phantom monk. A gate on the site would open itself; even after concreate had been used, the following day the gate was found open and bent.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Paddy Mulhall
info: The smell of smoke wafting along a corridor is attributed to the ghost of former owner Paddy Mulhall.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: General White
info: This general commanded the 17th lancers during the Crimea campaign and was thought to haunt a field close to where he was born.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Figure
info: A ghostly figure is said to stand by the fireplace here, while other witnesses are reported to have spotted orbs (whether in photographs or real life is not clear).

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lady in a Long Dress
location: Ballybrittas - Old Dublin Road close to Delaneys Roadhouse Bed and Breakfast
info: A driver swerved and suffered whiplash to avoid a woman in a long dress as she crossed the road, The driver tried looking for the woman but could not find her.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lamp
info: Walking home from the bus stop, two friends spotted an old style lamp moving towards them on the opposite side of the road. The light stopped and disappeared at the hedgerow where an old pub once stood. A local story says the ghost of Jack Adare, infamous for buying up bankrupt estates after the Great Famine, travels by lamplight.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Headless Figure
info: A phantom man who haunted the area was banished into the lake by a local priest. At some point during the banishment, the ghost lost his head.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: No Ploughing
info: A farmer who tried to plough this sacred land died after falling and banging his head. The two horses drawing the plough died the following day.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hearse
location: Ballylusk - Roads around an old burial ground
info: A man returning home after visiting the local public house was said to have encountered a phantom horse and cart containing a hearse.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tiny Footballers
location: Ballyroan - Marshy field west of village
info: A worker returning home took a shortcut across a marshy field and watched several tiny men playing football. The worker was told to kick the ball, but he was unable to touch it. When he finally did kick the ball, the worker was knocked to the ground. When he recovered, the tiny footballers had vanished.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fear
info: Some staff were said to avoid certain rooms in the museum, while visitors have reported cold spots, a sense of fear, and the feeling of being watched.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Queenie
info: More often felt rather than seen, the ghost here picked up the nickname Queenie.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dazzling Figure
info: A dazzling, coloured figure was seen standing in the second floor window of the old barracks by two brothers as they walked towards the building. More curious than scared, they investigated the site and realised there were no floors inside, so nowhere the figure could have stood.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Grey Lady
info: Folklore placed a phantom grey lady as haunting the Green Room in this country house.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Vanishing Hitchhiker
location: Mountrath - Unnamed road in the area
info: In this version of the vanishing hitchhiker story, a woman is picked up outside the town and asks to be dropped off at the top of the road which leads to the cemetery. If the woman is followed once she steps out of vehicle that has given her a lift, she is seen entering the cemetery and fading away.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Large Black Dog
location: Portlaoise - Exact area unknown, possibly Ridge Road
info: A black hound haunted the area where a man was once murdered.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Headless Horseman
location: Portlaoise - Green Mill Lane and/or Ridge Road
info: Local folklore says that the site of an old mill is home to a headless horseman. One version of the story says the horseman was a coach driver who failed to duck while passing under a low bridge.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Flying Coins
info: Coins were seen being thrown into the fountain by an unseen hand, and the witness later found three old ha'penny pieces in their pocket. A mobile phone on display in a Tesco store was thrown to the floor.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Young Girl
info: A dog walker claimed to have been frozen with fear after spotting a girl with a pale face laying on a gravestone. The witness heard screaming as they walked away from the site.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Accident Prone
location: Portlaoise - Road between Stradbally and Portlaoise
info: After dozens of serious and fatal accidents occurred along this road, a priest walked the distance reciting prayers. The accidents ceased to occur.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
info: Visitors to this piece of woodland after dark have been unnerved by footsteps and the feeling of being stalked.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Something
info: A vague entry in the Laois Burial Grounds Survey 2011 says that the word Dullow is used to describe a phantom, although details of the haunting are not given.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Large Hound
info: This area is reputedly haunted by a huge black hound which protects treasure buried somewhere under the structure. Another version of the legend says a swarm of rats and not a dog protect the treasure.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Richard Ely
info: Richard was shot in the castle by a poacher and has remained here since. One of the flagstones is still discoloured by his blood.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Funeral Procession
info: A out-of-place funeral procession passed through the village mid afternoon, although none of the locals recognised any of the mourners. It was later suggested that the procession dated from the Great Famine.

region: County Laois Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strange Light
info: This churchyard would be illuminated by unearthly light and night, and the locals whispered that fleeting white shapes could be seen darting between tombstones.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coffin Makers
info: The fairies which lived at this fort were said to have borrowed a man's hatchet to make a coffin for a neighbour's child two weeks prior to his death.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Cattle
info: A herd of phantom cattle was once said to walk around this area at night. The location was also home to a Puca which leapt upon a local man's back - he managed to stab the entity with a penknife and throw it to the ground. When he returned to the scene the following day, he found a wooden log with a knife-sized hole along one side.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Misty
location: Ballyconnell - Rocks close to Dara Fort
info: The area surrounding two circular rocks with a third placed on top is reputedly haunted.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Victorian Woman
info: The ghostly Green Lady that famously haunts a location in Ballyshannon was seen looking from a top floor window in a house in this area. The entity wore Victorian clothing.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mistaken Horse
info: A lad working on the fields near the lough spotted a stray pony and tied it to his harrow (a large rake). Unbeknown to the boy, the pony was in fact a water horse - the creature bolted to the lough, taking the lad with him. The lad's screams brought people running to the area, but it was too late - the lough was red with the boy's blood.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Peist
location: Lough Allen (Aillionn) - Waters of the lough
info: This lough is said to be home to a water monster, although no further information is available.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Finn's Dog
info: McCool's hunting dog, Bran, drowned in this body of water - the area was named after the faithful hound. Bran's ghost now haunts the lake.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Long Creature
location: Lough Bran (or Brin) - Waters of the Lough
info: Stories of this creature date back many years, thought the description varies considerably. The more recent sightings imply the monster to be a giant eel, greater than four metres in length.

region: County Leitrim Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Hunger Stone
location: Sliabh An Iarainn - Unknown stone at base of mountain
info: At the base of the Iron Mountain is a magical stone (fear gorta) said to create an insatiate appetite on any who stands upon it.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shadows in the Water
location: Ardpatrick - St. Patrick's Well, close to top of a hill
info: 'The Well of the Omen' by Dr Robert Dwyer Joyce states of this well 'Within it gaze the peasants to see what may befall: Who see their shadows down below, they will have merry cheer: Who see not any shadows shall die within the year'.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fast Moving Coach
date: Late nineteenth or early twentieth century
info: While driving along this road, Michael Fitzgerald heard the clattering of hooves close behind him. He pulled over to let whoever was behind him pass, but the sound suddenly stopped. After Fitzgerald began moving, the sound started again, and this time he was overtaken by a phantom coach pulled by ghostly horses.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sales Pitch
info: When put up for auction, one selling point which caught most news outlet's attention was the ghost which was said to haunt the building, a figure which would pass by one of the windows. Workmen on the site also said there was something peculiar with the house.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sleeping Army
info: A half human, half fairy entity sleeps beneath this hill along with an army waiting for the day they are needed to set Ireland free. The hybrid is said to ride across the nearby lake every seven years on a white horse with silver shoes.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fionn mac Cumhaill
info: This hill was said to be the first place Fionn mac Cumhaill appeared having killed Ceannurran, a one eyed giant.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fallen in Battle
info: This castle is reputed to be haunted by the souls of those who fell during the many battles on the site. The third floor is said to be home to a poltergeist (encountered by a cook and housekeeper during the 1960s), a ghostly builder named Henry appears on the staircase, and twentieth Earl of Glin still enjoys sitting on a particular armchair.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Lady
date: Prior to a death in the Langford family
info: The wife of a former Langford man, this woman now only appears before a death in the family.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Crying Tomb
location: Kilmallock - Abbey of Kilmallock - the White Stones
info: The pile of rubble that was once the tomb of Sir Maurice Fitzgerald, also known as the White Knight, is reputedly always wet no matter what the weather. Fitzgerald was cursed by a woman he had mortally wounded to weep for his crime, be he alive or dead.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fairy Riders
info: Beneath the castle a company of fairies on horseback wait for the day they are needed. The site is also reputed to be home to a phantom woman who wanders around carrying a candle.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fading Man
location: Limerick - Dunnes Stores (aka House of Garryowen)
info: One witness watched a fifty year old, grey haired man dressed in tweed slowly fade away, only to reappear and fade away again. An elevator would close its gates and move by itself, while a figure could be seen from the ground on the roof, but never found when the roof was searched.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Children
info: After carrying out a seance at the site, the Ghost Eire team said they could 'sense' children in wet clothing and two women.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Wall Walking
location: Limerick - Old Tom public house (no longer operating)
info: A ghostly man in this pub would be known for walking through walls. Unsurprisingly, the site also had a poltergeist, making no friends as it tossed bottles around.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Molly
info: Mentioned on RTE's Pulling With My Parents programme, it was claimed that a house along this street was home to an entity named Molly that took the virginity of one of the occupants. The family left their home after a poltergeist outbreak smashed plates and left handprints on the walls.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Humped Creature
info: While docked at Limerick, Captain Hugh Shaw and several of his crew reportedly spotted a creature with a three to four metre long neck and single hump moving up the Shannon.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Bishop's Lady
location: Limerick - Thomond Bridge and Castle Street
info: Locally named The Bishop's Lady, this woman is said to have been pushed over the bridge by her partner, drowning in the Shannon. She now looks for others to throw over the bridge. Fingernail-like scratches which can be seen in the bridge are said to belong to either the woman herself or one of her victims.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dead Hunt
info: Said only to be heard by older people, this phantom hunt consisting of invisible hounds would audibly manifest hours before the death of a local.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Giant's Gold
info: One myth says that alongside the giant's body is a golden hoard. The last time anyone tried to dig it up, a phantom bull could be heard, scaring the diggers away.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Lady of Kilcosgriff
info: The phantom white lady from Kilcosgriff Castle is said to have come to this building when a Major Langford died here. She was seen by a nurse treating the Major.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Earl Gerald
info: The earl is said to walk under Lough Gur, emerging on the back of a black horse every seven years to visit his former home. Another former earl, James, is also said to haunt the castle - he was murdered by his servants.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Armless Woman
info: A female spectre which haunted the churchyard was so terrifying that all who looked upon her died soon after. A local man banished the shade by slicing off her arm with his sword and praying for the rest of the night. In 2009 the Times newspaper carried the story that a tree stump contains the image of the Virgin Mary and Child, and that hundreds of visitors had come to the area to pray.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hound
info: This location may have once been home to a ghostly hound.

region: County Limerick Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Countess
info: It is said that this Countess was mistakenly buried alive under the altar. Her shadowy figure waits and occasionally cries out for her former husband to realise his mistake.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Monk
info: As AH Millar rode past the old burial ground, he spotted what he thought was a policeman in a long coat walking towards him. The figure vanished without warning. Millar later discovered that the site was haunted by a monk, the apparition said to be so common that no one would pass the area after sundown.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tree
info: Jim Sweeney appeared on national television sharing the story of the fairy tree on his land. Sweeney claimed that when the tree fell, he would be dead within a week, and as the last remaining member of the family, Jim worked tirelessly to keep the dying tree propped up to ensure his survival.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Rattling Buckets
info: A child carrying beer from the local pub to his home fell into the ditch and drowned after consuming much of his cargo. The rattling of his buckets could be heard in the area.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Famine Dead
info: A witness walked past a woman and two children who sat quietly on a wall. The witness knew them to be victims of the Great Famine.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Animal in Chains
location: Ballymahon - House along St Matthew's Terrace
info: Strange noises, including something resembling an animal in chains and loud pounding, and lights switching on and off resulted in the family living here moving out and into a caravan.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Captain Blundell
info: Blundell, a British officer, rides decapitated upon horseback in this area. His headless body was found in a nearby barracks, and an investigation ruled that the officer had killed himself. Some people thought this to be unlikely and believed his ghost had returned to prove that a murder had really occurred.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Snorting
info: A man renting this property was woken during the night by a loud snorting sound close by. Investigating, the man fainted after the sound occurred again right on top of him. He moved out, although the man said that during his first night in the new house, he was pushed out of bed by an unseen source. A similar event was reported by a previous lodger at Middleton House.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Wailing
info: The site of a former hospital, this barracks was claimed to be haunted by a wailing noise.

region: County Longford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dr Dubedat
info: Dubedat was the first doctor to be based at the old infirmary, and his skill much admired. After his death, his phantom periodically returned, and it was said his appearance heralded the death of a patient.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Waiting Army
location: Ardee - Dawson's Mount, aka Garret's Fort
info: An enchanted army of ten thousand men was said to be concealed within this hill - when the day comes for the troops to move out, they will slaughter all they come across until a red headed woman tells them they have killed enough.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coach
info: To see this phantom coach indicated that someone in the neighbourhood would soon die.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Henrietta Travescant
location: Carlingford - Carlingford Castle and Abbey ruins
info: A pirate before taking up the residency of Abbess, this woman is thought to be one of the pair of shades seen within the ruins.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Eel-like Creature
info: The lough is said to be home to a lake monster which resembles a rather large eel. The site featured in a few news outlets in 2019 after Adrian Shine, a Loch Ness Monster hunter, was invited to investigate the waters.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Carraig
date: Coins found 1989-2002, hunt occurs second Sunday of May
info: There was a flurry of Leprechaun activity on this mountain after a green suit and several gold coins discovered in 1989. Two years later, 'Leprechaun Whisperer' Kevin Woods claimed have contacted Carraig, elder for the 236 remaining leprechauns in the area. The little people are now protected in the area, and while there is an annual Leprechaun Hunt, the only things found are tiny cauldrons which have been left by the fairy folk themselves.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Red Girl
info: This figure was watched as she moved towards the door of the rectory, followed by a priest. Both figures vanished, though the girl has been seen since within the building.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tool Mover
info: Fairies would be blamed when gates were found left open and tools removed from their sheds, only to be found hanging in nearby trees.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: James II
info: James II stayed here just before his defeat at the Battle of the Boyne, and now his shade lingers on. He is not alone here, however. A crazy looking girl walks around the area with her hands caked in blood, while a soldier has been observed hanging by his neck from a tree.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Smashing Glass
info: CCTV caught a full beer glass breaking in two while on a table. While some people blamed a phantom, others said it was down to thermal stress.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Crunching Gravel
info: While photographing an eclipse of the moon, two friends heard footsteps walking along the gravel laying on the surface of the viaduct, although no one could be seen.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Noises
info: Boyne Paranormal Investigators visited the mostly deserted estate after four houses were reported to have strange events occurring within, including toys which would turn themselves on, banging, and the sounds of people moving around in empty rooms.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fleming and Golding
info: After Sir Edward Golding and his wife Elizabeth Fleming were drowned in a boating accident, their shades returned to haunt the area. The River Boyne is also the location where the tenth century poet Erard Mac Cossi threw a stone at a swan which fell to earth and transformed into a woman - she claimed to have been metamorphosed by demons who also travelled in the shape of swans.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Plunkett
info: Author Vikki Bramshaw claimed to have video recorded the ghost of Saint Oliver Plunkett, although there is a chance the ghost is a reflection. The ghost had not been seen before nor since.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hanging Woman
info: Unable to sleep, Frank K rolled over in his bed to turn on the lamp and spotted a woman standing with her back turned to him a couple of metres away. She had mousy brown curly hair in a ponytail tied with a black ribbon and was wearing a black and red vertically striped corset top with white puffy shoulders. Frank thought the woman had entered his bedroom by accident, before realising that she was floating off the ground, and that she had a rope around her neck which stretched towards the ceiling. The apparition quickly faded away.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Unpaid Rent
location: Drogheda - Unnamed horse near marshland (no longer standing?)
info: A tenant was taken to court for non-payment of rent for this property, claiming that a ghost had appeared to his wife and thrown something at her. The tenant was told this was no defence in law.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Centaur?
location: Drogheda - Unnamed road in the area
info: Two people travelling by car had to stop and wait for a couple of minutes after a horse with a human's face blocked the road. The terrified couple were frozen with fear and when the creature suddenly vanished, they turned around and drove home.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Old Murphy
location: Dundalk - Castletown Road leading to bridge
info: Murphy originally hailed from the area and took to haunting this stretch of road. The sounds of ghostly rattling chains and clattering feet would be heard moving along the road, only ceasing when they reached the Castletown bridge.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Builder
info: Rohesia de Verdon promised a builder that if he constructed her a castle, he could marry her. By the time construction was complete, Rohesia had changed her mind and had the builder thrown out of a high window and he died on the rocks below. His ghost can be heard moaning from beneath the window.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coach
info: A silent, phantom coach was once said to appear whenever a local person was close to death.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Giant's Grave
info: The Scottish giant Parrah Boug MacShagean built the dolmen at this site and challenged Fionn mac Cumhaill to combat. Fionn poisoned the nearby river and Parrah died from drinking the water. Parrah's body is said to lay in the nearby tomb. A legend says that if a visitor can manage to land three stones on to the dolmen, their wish shall be granted.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Heinous Horse
info: Two young adults driving along this road witnessed an otherworldly horse with the face of a man, the creature's eyes bulging from their sockets. The manifestation stood in the road, blocking their path for two minutes before vanishing.

region: County Louth Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
info: One man locking up the site heard footsteps coming down the staircase and approach him, although nothing could be seen. The man fled.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Vanishing Beach
date: Vanishes every seven years (timings slightly off in real life)
info: Folklore says the beach on the bay reappears every seven years before vanishing again. The truth is not that far off; a storm washed away all the sand in 2005, only for it to reappear in November 2017 following another spot of harsh weather.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Scaled Creature
info: One witness said that this lake monster looked like a dinosaur, with scales running down the back. Another viewer observed the monster on the lake bank - he described it as four metres in length, with a long neck and a sheep's head. It moved in little 'hops'. A photograph taken in 1968 of the monsters is unconvincing.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Donnell of the Yellow Hair
location: Belmullet - Stone on fortified hill, 4.5 miles southwest of town (current status not known)
info: A stone here marked the grave of the giant Dombnall Dual-Buidhe, or Donnell of the Yellow Hair. A dolman once marked the spot but had been removed by 1897.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Flying Lights
info: Several lights were said to move in formation from this fort to another on the far side of a nearby lake.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Ringer
info: A phantom at work in this unnamed farmhouse would ring the front doorbell and could also be heard walking up and door the stairs.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Nun
info: Viewers of a video produced by Frame Production that documented the history of the convent reported seeing a ghostly nun standing by a window in a brief shot. A manager with the production company was quoted in the press as saying he was not convinced that the figure was a ghost.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Trout
location: Cong - Cong Lake / Pigeon Hole cave
info: The trout is said contain the spirit of a woman who lost her husband to be. One man who caught the fish found it impossible to cook - after several attempts to roast the trout, the fish transformed into a beautiful woman demanding to be returned to her lake. The man did so.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: St Patrick
info: Climbers in the region sometimes hear the ring of a hand bell, which encourages them to keep climbing to the summit, though they never see the bell or bell ringer. The consensus of belief is that the bell is rung by St Patrick himself.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Playing Creatures
info: Four people watched several strange black creatures playing and diving around the surface of the lake. They said the animals were larger than horses, which they could see standing on the shoreline.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Godstone
date: Godstone pre twentieth century, Crane still present?
info: The Godstone was said to have granted islanders with control over the weather, credited with increasing the speed of potato growth, and could also put out fires. The stone was cast into the sea at some point in the nineteenth century after a religious man took exception to it. The islands were (or are) also home to an immortal crane - the bird is said to have sat alone from the dawn of time, waiting until the end of the world.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Our Lady
info: Fifteen people witnessed the apparition of Our Lady, Saint Joseph, and Saint John the Evangelist. Close by appeared a lamb and angels.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Wet Boar
info: While Fionn mac Cumhaill was hunting with his hounds Cullin and Conn, they encountered a boar with water leaking from its feet. He hunter and his dogs gave chase; the boar's leaking feet eventually creating Lough Cullin that enabled it to escape and drown Conn in the process.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dobhar Chu
location: Lough Mask - Waters of the lough
info: A man walking along the bank of Lough Mask had a narrow escape when a water beast jumped from the water and tried to drag him into the water. The man managed to escape and ran for his life. Another version of the story says the beast killed him. A creature seen in the lough during the 1960s was described as eel-like with two humps.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Black Hound
location: Pontoon - Crossing between Lough Conn and Lough Cullin
info: This area is reputedly home to a black spectral hound. The ghostly creature is said to cause fear in living dogs.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Cleaning Pans
location: Scotchfort - Unnamed farmhouse on the bank of Lough Conn
info: After dark, this property was filled with the sounds of doors being slammed, and pots and pans being noisily cleaned, although on investigation, no kitchenware was ever touched.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Serpent or Ghost
info: The treasure in this small body of water is protected by either an eel-like serpent or the ghost of a servant, or possibly both.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Cyclist
info: While taking a shortcut from the town heading to a Youthways, a witness spotted an approaching cyclist. The witness moved to one side to let the cyclist pass, but bike and rider vanished into the lake.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Cyclist
info: While walking towards the quay, a witness spotted a cyclist approaching. The cyclist was a middle-aged white male, wearing white shorts and struggled to cycle up the hill. The witness became momentarily distracted by a fly, during which the cyclist vanished, with no visible place to have gone. The witness's partner, walking alongside, had not seen the cyclist.

region: County Mayo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Annie O'Flynn
location: Westport - Ross House, between Westport and Newport
info: A former maid at the house, Annie was said by the owner to have appeared to him many years after her death. She has also been seen or heard by other family members. Other ghostly figures appear seated by the drawing room fire, and one man reported seeing a loathing face at the window.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Spotted Dog
info: A secret room in the moat was said to contain nine kegs of gold protected by a large black dog with a white spot. The only way to escape with the gold was to stab the dog three times with a dagger to the white spot.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Foxes
location: Gormanston - Area around Gormanston Castle (currently part of a college)
date: Prior to a death of a Viscount Gormanston
info: Whenever all the local foxes gather at the front door of the castle, a death will occur soon after.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Peter Fourth Earl of Fingall
info: The former Earl of Fingall has been observed a few times around the castle, always dressed in a blue coat and powdered wig. The library is also haunted by strange noises and moving furniture and fittings.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: House
info: A man dived to the bottom of the lough after making a wager that he could find something to bring up. He discovered an underwater house, in which he stumbled upon an old woman. She gave him a copper skillet to take back to the surface. As he left the house, the man was chased by a giant eel, but managed to escape.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Abducted Woman
location: Lough Sheelin - Waters of the lough
info: A farmer spotted a beautiful woman leave the lough and forced her to return to his farmhouse. Eventually she agreed to stay with him, on the condition that she never glazed upon the lake again. Twenty years passed and the farmer and the mermaid had several children. While waiting for the farmer to return from the fields on a clear day, the mermaid spotted the lough in the distance and fled towards it, never to be seen again.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man with Hound
location: Navan - Skyrne Castle, Hill of Tara
info: A phantom man, tall and covered by a cloak, once haunted this area, accompanied by his hunting hound. The area is also home to a shadowy nun and a woman in white who screams as she is chased by an unidentified shadow.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fairy Tree
location: Navan - Two hawthorn trees on the Hill of Tara
info: The two trees here belong to the fairies - damaging them, or even just taking a clipping, would result in bad luck befalling the perpetrator.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hovering Hitchhiker
location: Nobber - Country lane in the area
info: A local myth says that two people in a car stopped to offer a man standing by the roadside a lift, believing him to be a hitchhiker. The person on the passenger side then noticed the figure was hovering above the ground. The people drove away at speed.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dropped by a Witch
location: Oldcastle - Loughcrew passage tombs, aka Slieve na Calliagh (Hill of the Witch)
info: In a ritual to grant her great power, a witch leapt around the hills here, dropping stones which formed the cairns. However, on her fourth jump she stumbled and died, her body forming Patrickstown Hill.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Nun
info: This ghostly nun was once watched as she slowly dissolved into nothingness. She has also been heard walking in empty parts of the building, though the footsteps could belong to a white woman (thought to be a murdered maid) who also haunts the castle.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Puck
info: The Puca which resided at the castle was considered its protector and would take the form of a large hound or small steed. The entity wore a chain around its neck regardless of form, so was always recognisable.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Shattering Cross
info: A large stone cross which once stood on the village green was said to have risen from the ground before shattering with such force that pieces were recovered from Teltown, some twelve miles westwards.

region: County Meath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sky Ship
location: Tailltenn (now known as Teltown) - Exact area not known
info: Conghalach Cnoghbha, High King of Ireland, and his men were said to have spotted a sailing ship in the sky here. A crew member of this ship threw a spear at a salmon, also in the sky, which missed and landed close to Conghalach. The crew member leapt from the ship and, swimming in the sky, came down to the ground to retrieve the spear. One of the King's men grabbed the swimmer, who screamed out 'I'm drowning!'. Conghalach told his man to release the crew member, who 'swam' back to the ship which then disappeared into the clouds.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Stoned Monster
info: Three boys watched a weird water creature playing in the lake - they threw stones at the creature and ran when it approached them. They stated it had a hairy, horned head.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Famine Victims
info: This former workhouse is reportedly haunted by ghosts dating back from the Great Famine.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Banker
info: A woman sitting on the banks of this lake watched a ghostly figure in a tweed suit jump into this body of water. Just over a week later, a banker took his life at the same spot.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Lamp Carrier
location: Clones - Road between Clones and Scarva
date: Lamp holder unknown, shawled woman circa 1997
info: Travelling along the road carrying a candlelit lamp under one arm, this tall shadowy figure wearing a long cloak is thought to have once been murdered in the area. One witness walking through the area spotted an older woman wearing glasses and a shawl. The witness knew something was wrong but did not mention the encounter to anyone. A few years later a friend mentioned that they had driven along the road and thought they had hit a shawled woman but found no evidence of a collision.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Armed Creature
location: Drumate Lough (also referred to as Dromate) - Waters of the lough
info: A farmer claimed to have shot at a creature in this lough after it passed within two metres on his boat. The monster, described as being seven-foot (2.13 metres) in length, had two arms that had claws (or webbing). The creature dived under the surface.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Date with Death
info: Picking on the last person to leave a funeral to have occurred here, this phantasm manifests as a beautiful woman in front of male witnesses and as a gorgeous man for female viewers. It acts as a real person, setting a date when it can next meet with the mortal, before vanishing into thin air. The date agreed upon is when the witness dies.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Norman
info: When Lady Marjorie's son died in World War I, his form appeared to the woman as she sat in bed. Mistaking the ghost for a real person, she tried to speak to Norman, only to watch him fade away. He has been seen since in the same room. The castle is also haunted by Lady Constance, who died in 1925.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Uncle Moreton
info: Author Shane Leslie encountered his dead Uncle Moreton while visiting his family home. Moreton warned the man that his other uncle would not be impressed by a recent article Leslie had penned. It turned out to be the truth.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: In Want of Mary
info: An ethereal old man walks along the road calling the name 'Mary'. It is believed that his wife Mary was robbed and murdered along the street sometime in the eighteenth century.

region: County Monaghan Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Armoured Man
info: A male apparition wearing full armour reputedly walks along the road and sits at a drinking pool in this area. It is thought the apparition dates from the Plantation of Ulster.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Giant's Stone
info: The giant Fionn MacCumhaill tossed this stone from Croghan, around twenty kilometres southeast. As the stone rolled across the ground, a dog stood in its path and stopped the stone with his paw; the paw print is still seen on the stone today.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Anchor
info: During Mass, the congregation at this church were interrupted as an anchor dropped from the sky and caught on the church door. The people investigated and spotted a ship floating above them; one of the crew diving overboard and swimming towards them through the air towards the anchor. The congregation grabbed the sailor, but the bishop demanded that they let him go. As the group released the man, he floated upwards and once on board the ship, someone cut the rope attached to the anchor - the ship sailed off into the sky. The anchor was said to have been on display at the church.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Thin Man
info: Spotted by a man driving past the ruins at night, this gaunt figure appeared to be bathed in misty light.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Floating Candles
info: Strange lights were constantly reported floating around within the building before conversion into a family home in 1991. Since then, other ghosts have been reported within, including an old man seen sitting by the fireplace and a woman in a red dress.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sarah Blundell
info: The phantom Lady Blundell, who died in 1701, periodically appears on the lawn surrounding the ruins of the castle. Folklore says there is a network of tunnels leading away from the site.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Gold Protector
info: The castle is haunted by a spirit that protects a hidden pot of gold. If the treasure is removed from the castle, it is said that the ghost will not rest until it has returned the pot to the hiding place.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tall Man
info: The ghost of a tall man would appear on the staircase of this manor house. After an arson attack burned the building to the ground, locals claimed to have seen a ghostly ball of fire moving around the estate.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Princess
info: The village takes its name from a myth which says a princess named Eitigh is buried beneath the location.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hugh
info: This spooky monk, nicknamed Hugh, walks around the castle many centuries after his death, and is said to communicate future events to those who want to listen.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Devil's Room
info: The local priest offered to play cards with the first owner of the house, who responded, 'I'll rather play cards with the devil'. When the devil turned up at the house to take the owner up on his offer, the room where the horned one waited was promptly bricked up (and remains so to this day). The property is also haunted by several ghosts, including horses that are heard galloping but never seen.

region: County Offaly Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Blue Girl
info: This young girl fell while playing on the staircase, dying on the floor below. Her ghost is seen on the stairs or felt rushing past witnesses. The other spooks include a young boy (seen in the same location as the blue girl), a dark hooded woman accompanied by a party of monks, laughing children in a former nursery room, and the sounds of two Englishmen becoming drunk!

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Faces at the Windows
info: Built on a site of Celtic ceremony, many people have reported seeing weird faces peering out of the windows.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fighting Fairies
info: A farmer from Sheemore (Co Leitrim) who once helped the fairies had his cattle taken by bailiffs. The bailiffs drove the cattle for a few miles before being intercepted by the fairies at a bridge, where the bailiffs were beaten by invisible foes and scared away. Legend says this is how Battlebridge received its name.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Green Lady
info: Soldiers stationed at the barracks reported seeing this green lady as she patrolled the area. Some claimed the ghost to be a former servant at the house who descended into madness and hid herself away in a vegetable cupboard.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Exorcism?
info: Castlerea Prison hit the news after claims that an exorcism was required to dismiss strange paranormal activity occurring in the gym. Governor Dan Scannel denied the reports.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coote?
info: The upper part of the tower attached to the house is said to be haunted by a man from the Cromwellian period, possibly by the name of Coote.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Bailiff
info: When empty, locals avoided this building, considering it haunted by a ghostly bailiff who wore a pot around his neck. A priest managed to trap the entity in a room which was soon bricked up.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Mills
info: The ghost of Mills, a High Sheriff, had been trapped in a room in this house, but briefly escaped during renovations and brought misfortunate to the household.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Black Pig
location: Kiltrustan - Road close to old plantation
info: A phantom black pig made itself known to children. Adults standing in the same area could not perceive it, even when the children shouted that the entity was running around their feet.

region: County Roscommon Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Man Carrying Stone
location: Strokestown - Hilly road in the area
info: It was once not uncommon to see the ghost of a figure carrying a large mill stone along this road.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Just William
info: Another building haunted by W B Yeats, Yeats himself saw the ghost of one of his friends on the staircase. The site is also reported to be the home of two phantom women who walk through the garden carrying flowers and paints.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pippa
info: A mischievous ghostly child nicknamed Pippa who would lock doors and drop items can be appeased by giving her gifts. The cellar is home to another paranormal entity.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Armada Figure
info: A local Sligo man featured in the local press after photographing a 'glowing figure' walking on water at Streedagh Beach. The witness thought the apparition related to the Spanish Armada, from which a ship floundered in Streedagh Sound in 1588.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Storm Calmer
date: Nineteenth century practice, unknown if still well present
info: If a storm raged, the water of this well could be drained into the sea. As the contents reduced, so would the force of the storm.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Pair of Dadharchu
location: Lake Glenade - Waters of the Lake
info: Translated their name means 'Hound of the Deep'; two Dadharchu lived in this lake until one of the beasts killed and ate a young bride. Her husband exacted revenge by shooting one of the creatures and taking a sword to the other. Regardless whether this is myth or legend, there have been reports in the twentieth century of four metre long creatures seen swimming in the lake.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Tapping
info: William Butler Yeats spent some of his childhood here, later writing that he and his siblings would hear the ghosts of long-gone smugglers tapping on the windows. A smuggler known as John (or Jack) Black had originally built the house.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Footsteps
location: Sligo - Private apartment close to cemetery
info: Items would disappear around this property, only to turn up again elsewhere. Five people on the site all heard stomping feet from the empty rooms on the floor above.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Egyptian Curse
info: Poltergeist activity broke out in the house shortly after the arrival of Egyptian and Syrian artefacts brought back from the Middle East by Owen Phibbs. Servants were driven away, while the house sometimes shook to the very foundations. Eventually the family moved away and left the house to rot.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Sound of Firearms
location: Streedagh - Somewhere along the Sligo/Bundoran road
info: Ten years after an ambush occurred on the site, a witness returning home reported hearing gunfire and seeing misty shapes in wearing peaked caps.

region: County Sligo Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Spanish Soldiers
info: The abbey is reputedly haunted by the ghosts of Spanish Sailors who were brought here and executed by British soldiers in 1588, after a vessel from the Spanish Armada. The ghostly presences manifest as shadowy forms accompanied by a cold atmosphere.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Family Friend
info: Two brothers, aged eight and ten years old, noticed a man peering over the wall of this graveyard. His head and shoulders were visible, and the figure wore a white shirt with dark glasses and had curly hair. The man also looked like he had been crying and ignored the children when they spoke to him. The children told their father, who pointed out the wall was eight feet high; upon hearing the description of the figure, the father recognised it as being a friend of his who died four years previous.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Music
info: Fairies could once be heard making music under this artificial hill.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Black Blob
location: Cappagh White (or Cappawhite?) - Road approaching Ironmills bridge
info: While travelling on his bicycle, Thomas Fahey stated that a strange black blob landed on his handlebars. The weird entity slowed the bicycle down considerably, before moving off and disappearing along a path.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Coach
info: The rector living here reported hearing what sounded like a coach being driven in the hallway, always between 20:00h and 00:00h. A phantom horse and trap were sometimes seen outside of the building.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Ambush
location: Clogheen - Knockmealdown Mountains, close to the monument site
info: The sounds of fighting and gunfire is occasionally said to repeat in this area.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Petticoat Loose
location: Clogheen - Large pond in the Knockmealdown Mountains
info: The monster known as Petticoat Loose has a body like that of a horse, while the head takes the form of a woman. When it appears (which is rare), the creature asks, 'When will the day of judgement come?' before disappearing back under the water.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Princess Orloff
info: The shade of Orloff, a former Russian Princess, was reported by a caretaker who looked after the building after it fell empty. Her coach could also occasionally be heard setting off along the driveway, driven by her loyal butler.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Strange Voices
location: Clonmel - Former drapery shop, O'Connell Street
info: The strange voices and sounds heard by occupants of the building transpired to be only the beginning. Over a period of weeks, screaming, laughing were reported from the site, together with bedclothes thrown through windows and furnishings knocked over. The constabulary and the sightseers who flocked to the site were unable to find who were responsible, and the outbreak suddenly ceased.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Woman
location: Clonmel - Unnamed road leading southwards, passing over a bridge
date: Late nineteenth or early twentieth century
info: Walking to a friend's house late at night, this witness spotted a glowing woman in white with long hair cross a bridge ahead of him. The girl vanished without trace, and upon mentioning it when he arrived at his destination, his friend told him that the same figure had appeared at the foot of his bed a few nights previous.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Hound
info: A black dog haunted this stretch of road, although there have been no sightings for at least one hundred years.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Flying Coke
info: A few strange occurrences are said to have occurred here, such as doors which open and close unaided, a Coke bottle which flew through a doorway, and heavy items which move themselves in the kitchen. One barmaid claimed to have seen a man in the bar who had died two weeks previous - he tipped his hat to her before leaving the room.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Secret Tunnel
info: A secret tunnel said to exist between Friars Lough and the village contained treasure hidden by monks.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Edmond Roe O'Kennedy
info: Edmond was murdered in the sixteenth century before telling anyone where he had concealed his hidden treasure. Since his death, Edmond's shade has appeared to visitors at the ruined site, blood leaking from a large slit in his throat.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Fire Breathing Hound
info: This abomination with cloven hooves protects a hidden hoard of treasure somewhere near this house.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Galley
location: Lough Derg - Waters of the lake
info: Always travelling north, this phantasmal vessel traverses the lake with gentle singing emanating from it.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Finn the Monster Killer
location: Lough Derg - Waters of the Lake and surrounding area
info: A legend tells of how the Warrior Hero Finn fought and killed a huge monster which lived in this lake - two hundred men climbed out of the beast's belly once Finn sliced it open. Some say a (smaller) lake creature still lives in the water.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Suicide
info: The ruins of this castle are reputedly haunted by a man who killed himself within.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Negative Energy
info: Shortly after moving into their home, the Mitchell family found themselves subjected to loud banging, cold breezes, and a 'negative energy' that caused sleeplessness and distress to their children. After engaging a priest, medium, energy diviner and shamanic healer, the family finally found peace.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: No Females
location: Roscrea - Inishnameo, ruined church (may also be known as Monahinsha?)
info: Two islands could be found here. On the larger island, it was said that no female of any species could land upon it. On the smaller island, no one could die - the sick would become worse until they could not stand the pain, only dying after being removed from the site by friends.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Night Coach
info: Carrying the shades of the Parker-Hutchinson family, this phantom coach travels towards their former home.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Screaming
info: Screams followed by the sound of a body being dragged down a staircase persist in haunting this castle, thought to be the result of a body being dropped down the stairs.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Broken Tooth
info: This mountain is so named after Old Nick took a bite from it - he broke a tooth in the process, which formed the Rock of Cashel.

region: County Tipperary Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dyer
info: A policeman named Dyer once swore to protect the area 'dead or alive'. After his death in 1860, locals reported his ghost carrying out his promise.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Richard Costen
info: Richard died trying to escape from the law for a crime he did not commit. He can be heard screaming, choked to death on the reins of his horse. The spectral Jeremiah Coghlan reportedly rides on the back of a white horse - if seen, the viewer will die within a year. Finally, Sir Francis Prendergast, a psychotic murderer, stalks nearby woodland.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Nellie Flemming
location: Ardmore - Whiting bay to Glencairn Beach
info: Two groups of fishermen half a mile out to sea observed a large fishing boat heading towards them. Even though the boat made no sound and did not create any waves, the fishermen pulled back their nets fearing that the vessel contained customs officers and hid in the nearby coves for the boat to pass - but it had vanished. A fortnight later, a huge storm hit the area and a local schooner named 'Nellie Flemming' was lost without trace, and the fishermen became convinced that the 'Nellie Flemming' was the strange boat they had seen.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Curse of Ballinacourty
location: Ballinacourty - Ballinacourty house (no longer standing), and general area
info: A mother whose son was hanged by a local sheriff for being 'lazy' cursed all who lived in the area to endure the heartbreak she felt.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: The Magicians
info: It was said that the original owners were magicians and that one of their spirits remained in the house. Sickness plagued one of the occupants, but when they moved out in 1968, the illnesses ceased.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Older Man
info: A phantom old man was reputedly seen on this road.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Gunman
info: It is claimed this location is haunted by a gunman shot dead by the British in 1921.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Moving Mary
info: The statue of the Virgin Mary animated on this day, speaking to visitors and answering their questions.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Woman
info: A former smuggling haunt, a ghostly woman is said to move around in the kitchen, while an unseen hand pours beers. Other female form is said to pass through walls. The group GhostEire reported recording a female voice say 'Jack' when they visited the site.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Woman
info: The abbey was once haunted by a young woman dressed in white. She was seen and heard moving in the upper part of the building, though it is said the haunting stopped once a Major discovered a heart in a metal box in the attic and gave it a proper burial.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Beresford's Banshee
date: Prior to a death in the Beresford family
info: Lord Charles Beresford gave an interview with the London Daily Mirror in 1907 where he claimed the wailing of a banshee at Curraghmore House announced the death of his brother Lord Delaval in Canada. The ghost of Lord Tyrone may have also visited Lady Beresford here, an event also claimed to have occurred at Dromore's Gillhall Estate.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Second Earl of Tyrone
info: The Second Earl of Tyrone and Nicola Hamilton agreed that the first one to die should appear post-mortem to the other. Many years later at Gill House, Nicola (now Lady Beresford) encountered the ghost of the Earl, who touched her wrist. The spectre left a blackened mark and caused the joint to shrivel up; Lady Beresford covered the area up with a black ribbon which she never removed. It is worth noting that the same story is told about a house in Dromore.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Repairs
info: The ferry owners would allow the people of Youghal to use their services free of charge when transporting a coffin and pallbearers. Some men from Youghal realised the evening before a local death, they could hear the ferry being repaired at night, so they crossed the river to investigate. From their vantage point in the undergrowth, the men observed workers surrounding the ferry, a few recognised as decreased who had previously made the ferry crossing in caskets.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Presence
info: Several unconfirmed stories speak of this location being haunted, but no one can say for sure by whom or what.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: White Nun
location: Waterford - Back roads of Presentation Convent
info: Little is known about this ghostly white nun who walks along the roads after dark.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Force
location: Waterford - By the old infirmary, towards John's Park / Polberry Cross Road
info: A witness walking home in the early hours of the morning was pushed two metres by an unseen force. No one else could be seen. The witness said the sensation resembled a push from a horse and was one of their worst experiences.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Banshee
info: A banshee is said to have been observed sitting on walls around the city centre, wailing whilst brushing her hair. Her cries are said to upset nearby dogs.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Nurse
info: After the nun/nurse who set up the operating room died, the room continued to be found tidy and in order at the start of the day.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Dark Haired Woman
location: Waterford - Private house in the Grange area
info: A family reported that a middle-aged woman with her dark hair tied up in a bun had haunted their home for twenty years. She often stood on the staircase, watching the occupants go about their business.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Light Switching
info: A resident here reported all the lights in the house turning themselves off (without the trip switch kicking in), footsteps being heard, and the kettle turning itself on.

region: County Waterford Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Jack Hayson
info: Eli Hayson peered from the window of his house which overlooked the quay and watched his twin brother Jack emerge and come running towards him. Jack appeared terrified and was being chased by three men. Before Eli had a chance to act, all four figures vanished. Not long after, Eli heard that his brother had drowned at Cork, fifty miles away.

region: County Westmeath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Horse and Rider
info: This stone is carved with scenes which could depict an ancient battle. One legend says that at certain times of the year a horseman manifests and gallops around it. Another story states that a man named Michael will one day find two pots of gold under the stone.

region: County Westmeath Ghosts, Folklore and Paranormal Places
title: Blue Lady
